reviewText:
I would have loved to add a ton more, but this is the limit I can.

PROS:Extremely diverse class system. Many different ways to build your character, but limited (Reason in cons).
Huge map to explore.
Many levels giving it an interesting goal to get to cap. Current cap at this time is upwards of nearly 300 levels.
Many items to gear your character. Most classes can go 1h + offhand/shield or 2handed weapon allowing you to go tanky or focus dps.
You generate TP (In-game Cash Shop currency) overtime, to a maximum of 5 TP. You can use this to get several items which includes Megaphones to use global chat (or shout chat for this game.
Cosmetics can have stat improvements to buff your character. (Con below to go with this.)
Collections are rewarding by giving you bonus' for completing them. These bonus' are also carried across your entire Team (family/characters). (Con below to go with this.)
Fairly large storage which can be upgraded is a nice change from games which only allow 10-20 items to be stored.
Upgrading gear isn't NEARLY as challenging as some other games making it nice to be able to upgrade gear. Your fail chance" never drops below 51%.
I feel this should be here. The game has a lot of grinding
date:
you get to points in the level curve that you've completed all quests on both sides of the map and the next area is 10+ levels above you. You are forced to grind for 5-10 levels unless you've saved your EXP cards you get from questing to boost you through the curve and over to the exp reset. This can both be a pro and con since some people like the grind and some people hate it.

CONS:No P2P trading for free users. Even Token is limited to 30 trades a month.
Can't trade Silver (In-game general currency) through trading.
Extremely limited AH

reviewText:
Strongly recommend this for veteran MMORPG players
If you're in for a long, detailed read then proceed. That's just my writing style. If not then there's a TL;DR at the bottom.

If you're a veteran MMORPG player from the golden age of MMORPG's, you've come to the right place. Tree of Savior is just about the only MMORPG to release in this decade that caters exactly to those that are fond of hardcore MMORPGs of an age long ago. The style, feel, input and feedback of the game pays much homage to MMORPG titles such as Ragnarok Online. In fact, the original director of Ragnarok Online is the director for this game. You can rest assured that this game will keep you busy with lots to do and much fun to be had.

Now let's get into the actual critic. This is actually my first review but I've played MMORPG's my entire life and have played this title for more than my actual listed play time.

PROS :

Extreme class diversity
Unique class system
Customizable stat distribution
Rustic, nostalgic art style
Amazing soundtrack
Hidden sub-quest lines
Randomly generated events
Support-type player friendly!
Boss monsters have attack patterns
Alright. Let's put everything into context.

First and foremost is definitely the rustic feel of this game. The art style, atmosphere, music, everything just plays so well into constructing an amazing world for you to explore. The art style is extermely reminiscent of Ragnarok Online and some view Tree of Savior as the true" sucessor to Ragnarok Online. You have all the amazing customizability and environment from Ragnarok Online put into a much more modern take on the same genre without losing it's original feel.

The biggest attraction of Tree of Savior would definitely have to be the class system. Tree of Saviors class system is very unique in that a player can custom tailor their class to fit their specific play style. Are you a "Swordsman" class but prefer to use many new active skills instead of basic attacks? Advance into "Highlander" or "Barbarian" to progress down those paths and gain access to a whole new branch of skills. But maybe you enjoy using basic attacks. If that's the case
date: you can choose to further hone your skills as a "Swordsman" and invest further into your original first class instead of advancing into a "Highlander" or "Barbarian". Tree of Savior gives players the opportunity to "Rank up" their current class instead of advancing to a new class and increase the maximum skill levels of their current class' abilities
recommended: giving them potential to be stronger than those that followed a different path if utilized correctly.\n\nTree of Savior also encourages players to diversify their class choices to fit their play style. Just because you chose the path of a Wizard and advanced into a Pyromancer doesn't mean you're stuck being a flame based magic user forever. You can easily advance into a Cryomancer at the next class advance and become both! Just because you chose the path of magic doesn't mean your only role is damage dealing. You can advance into other classes that compliment your current set of skills as well. A Pyromancer has the ability "Flame Ground" which sets an area ablaze dealing Damage over Time. Should a Pyromancer also advance into a "Linker"
hoursPlayed: a class that specializes in monster manipulation
voteText: the "Pyro-Linker" could set ground abalaze
helpfulPercent: "link" together monsters
votesHelpful: and drag them over the fire to be slow roasted. There are plenty of classes with complimenting skills such as this example. The greatest thing about Tree of Savior is finding them all and trying them.\n\nCustomizable stat distribution is a very big thing for me. It means that the game does not have a "preset" style of playing that the game has already defined for you. If you feel like being a warrior class that goes complete glass cannon and forsakes all durability put everything into Strength and have at it. If you feel like playing a Wizard up close and personal you can easily stat in some extra Vitality for some health. If you feel that you want to shoot arrows faster rather than harder
votesTotal:
you can easily stat in Agility for some speed. Being able to customize your stat inputs helps you refine what your playstyle would be instead of just following along a guide.


Now onto the cons. A game without cons does not exist. But Tree of Savior has some debateable cons so let's get into them.

CONS:

Linear Leveling system
Bizarre map layout
Segregated maps
Grind

Tree of Savior players on a linear leveling system of starting at level 1
votesFunny: to infinity. That is to say
commentsCount: there is no level cap. In concept
column16: this is designed so that players play at their own pace because there is no race to a "end game" goal to do content. Players will just play at their own leisure finishing content as they progress into different worlds and areas. However players must be reminded that this was originally a Korea MMORPG. It takes alot. alot. Of grinding to progress speedily. In my humble opinion this is actually a good way to gate players from speeding through the entire games' content in a single week. But in a game whoms biggest emphasis is replayability by creating multiple characters in different classes
column17: it just slows down progress a ton and doesn't feel great. Grind is both a necessity but a gimp when it comes to MMORPG designing. In all honesty comparatively to other MMORPG's
column18: the grind isn't so bad but it is there nonetheless.\n\nThis may be a smaller point but the map layout for Tree of Savior is a bit strange. You'll be progressing linearely through the game and maps and everything will be placed within your level zone
column19: but should you decide to explore a bit the map directly underneath your level 20 map could be a level 100+ map. Now the monsters won't instantly agro and oneshot you or anything
column20: infact they won't agro you at all if you're out of the level gap
column21: but it's just a bit strange unless you're the explorative type. Because of the linear map progression based on current level
column22:
you'll never really re-visit older maps save for farming specific materials or major towns and adjacent fields.


My conclusion for this game is you should definitely try it. Whether you're an MMORPG Veteran or a newbie to the genre the experience playing it was amazing and you won't experience another game like it.

reviewText:
I have a level 230 Shinobi, and a Pardoner/Buffer thats aiming to become an Oracle someday.. i'll give you my thoughts about this game:

Tree of Savior is being runned by a publisher called IMC

IMC made some pretty dumb decisions on how to handle RMT & Gold Farmers, they've put restrictions on almost everything, while RMT are still trading talt to their buyers and those players sell it to npc for 5k each, every other legit suffers from marketplace queues and trade restrictions

The game is very poorly optimized even on high end PC's.. its funny because there was no performance issues during iCBT.. this all started to happen after they do a maintenence and it gets worst everytime they do it

We've got a few elitist f&%kers camping Dullahan and other popular world bosses to farm cubes, yes just a party of 6 ~ 12 people and they pretty much own the market, things that people want to buy are not listed on the marketplace and nobody is selling because they aim on inflating everything via high demand.. which seems to be working very well for them

There are many cool community made addons that wasnt officially approved by IMC yet, and TOS is a VAC enabled game.. lately i've been seeing top 10 players disappearing from the rankings and nobody knows why

Dungeons are always bugged, either theres a problem queueing due to a large influx of players doing the same thing, you would get booted to the login screen over and over until you finally get in, IMC have given some decent compensation for it over the past few weeks, but after the recent 24 hour (yes one full day) maintenence, nobody has recieved compensation at all!

I'm not new to the MMO scene, I played pretty much every game out there for nearly two decades.. One of my favorite things about it is the International community, everyone speaks different languages, everyone has a different grind, a different strategy on doing things.. Tree of Savior has the most toxic, most racist playerbase i've ever seen!

They pretty much runned the Brazilian players off the server! Some are to blame for recent exploiting, but others were really nice.. anyway they're all gone now. IMC moved them to a different server and there goes 1/3 of my friends list, the few that are left are being automatically blocked due to some bug after the previous maintenence, so I currently have nomore friends.

I'm writing this here because I wanted to write about it at the forums, but I'm constantly getting 404 errors or the forums would not load at all.. yeah i'm getting tired of this game and it hasn't even fully launched yet
Already bought the expansion to Guild Wars II and thats where i'm going.

So to anybody thats waiting on this game, or dying to play it.. don't get your hopes up its gonna be a big waste of time and disappointment, no doubt the game will be overrun by gold spammers and botters once its F2P

reviewText:
It is hardly worth reviewing this game, given the hype around it is so high that people couldn't care less about listening to other's views on it. There are many videos on youtube covering this game, guides, wikis and many other material, so if you haven't already clearly decided that this is the best game ever, you probably haven't seen enough of internet latelly, or maybe you aren't yet convinced that it is that great of a game.

If you meet any of the last cases, then maybe my review will see an use in your screen.

First of all I do not recommend this game, based on my own personal reasons, expectations, and experience with playing in two betas, and open release.

(1). Obligatory Linear Questing.

Be not swayed by the similarity and countless links to Ragnarok Online, which is the main reason of the hype surrounding this game. Tree of Savior's experience is hardly anything similar to it.

Instead of keeping it's Soul Predecessor"'s legacy of open and free to explore world and lore

reviewText:
Initial impressions. I've separated the game itself from the publisher's handling of it because that's a different, much uglier, can of worms.

Pros
+ Great music
+ Great art
+ Some aspects of combat, like landing hits, feel satisfying
+ Some of the quest objectives are creative
+ Versatile class advancement system

Cons
- Linear progression
- Lifeless story
- Player trade is locked behind a monthly paywall. This includes players who have paid trying to trade with players who haven't. It's sub-to-sub only.
- Account-wide storage is locked behind a monthly paywall. If there is a method to transfer items to alts without subbing, I'm not aware of it.
- Grind-heavy. Not a con on its own, more on this later.
- Unchallenging combat
- Unforgiving class/skill selection. Do research ahead of time because any mistakes made are permanent.
- Outdoor quest credit is not shared between all players taking part, only party members. This means that if there are fifty players in one area waiting for a quest mob to spawn, it will take at least 10 respawns of that mob for all players to finish the quest, assuming they only need to kill it once and all 50 players are in parties of 5. This is made worse by the current respawn timers, more on this later.
- Dungeons are very widely staggered level-wise and have a daily entrance level of 2. One run takes about 10 minutes to complete.
- Questing alone is not enough to progress.

Current publisher issues
- Heavy server-side lag
- Gold seller spam is rampant. There isn't much the company can do about this this early on.
- Respawn timers are extremely long, somewhere in the realm of 1~2 minutes, while monsters die extremely quickly and are highly contested. This inflates the grind by forcing players to simply sit in one area waiting for the next wave of respawns because they cannot progress otherwise. Progression is entirely linear and all players must go through the same areas in the same order to quest, so questing areas are always full of players competing for quest credit on the next wave of respawns. Quests that could be completed in minutes may take much longer depending on how many waves of respawns you end up sitting through.

Final thoughts
While I plan to play this game a bit longer, it's not something I would recommend to friends or something I see myself playing in the long-term. I play it because Ragnarok is dead and this reminds me of it, but the visuals are where the resemblance ends. Progression and questing are riddled with poor design choices that the industry outgrew over a decade ago, the servers are overcrowded, and current respawn timers make play unpleasant. For all of its flaws though, it does look and sound pretty.

2016/04/05 Update
An update has made the game much more playable. Some of the worst issues have been fixed (server stability, dungeon queues, and respawn rate were all addressed), though many still remain. The market issues are on being worked on and if they're also changed I'll update this again with a thumbs up. While the game is definitely in a better place than last week, the player trade restrictions, storage restrictions, and 48 hour waiting period to receive your money from sold auctions are all still in place. It's difficult to recommend a game where these features exist.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Great soundtrack
- Large variety of classes
- Creative class themes and skillsets
- Beautiful sprites
- Great monster design
- Great visual feedback (monsters explode on death, the screen shakes, lots of pretty colors, etc. which is extremely significant in a grind-centric game)

Cons:
Content is VERY streamlined.

- Every single player is funneled through the same maps, in the same order, killing the same bosses, doing the same quests. The world map is set up like a giant flowchart. This really hurts the immersion of the game, and in my opinion, is one of its largest flaws. The maps are made specifically to get the player from level x to level y, rather than being an explorable part of the game's world. Every time you outlevel a map, that part of the world becomes useless to you. All of these beautiful areas that you explore become void after you complete" them because the developers only created them for the express purpose of leveling you through a certain range. This makes the game just seem like a series of rooms rather than a virtual world.

Boss fights are boring.

- They seem cool at first

reviewText:
BEWARE - LONG POST Edited 28/4/16  [ Lv 180 ]

TLDR - A good game for niche players. For players who prefer a less grindy and expect   instant graftication  and less premium features for payers, this may not be the game for you. This game has its flaws, but the developers passion for it can be shown in thier effort to listen to the community at times.

New update -
The past week has been quite a breath of fresh air reports on bots and gold seller BANNED and relocation of actual server to respective zones, this makes my ping 15... omg..


After playing more than 220 hours, for all its flaws, it brings me back to mmorpg of old times of grind fest.(beside the market and trade restriction, IMC is trying this to control the gold seller and bots). However the core of the game, grinding and looting, unique classes building for pve; pvp or gvg remains there.

While i feel the token restriction is broken for people who do not pay and those who complain.. why not give a consideration that they did not pull the game out of thier butt for free, i mean just get a token and play. In which i must say you could probably grind out to buy ANOTHER TOKEN in the market! (its pretty easy to earn silver at higher level)

This game is flawed in some areas, but it does bring it back up with its cool classes, artwork and loveee the music. Some aspect of the game is still unpolished, like game graphic optizimation, stronger anti cheat shield, refining the trade system,more detailed skill descriptions. its a diamond in the rough.

(for ppl who wonder why only a single class can form a guild.. i would say i rather not have tons of small self contained guilds crowding server spaces but huge guilds that engage in huge battles.

Lastly This game is free in the middle of may.


EDIT - i read through the negatives and my thoughts.
1- Bots
2- Farming/drop rate system
3- killsteal
4- people/bots spamming shout
5- bugs/coding issue
6- class balance
7 - p2w and headgears
8 - market/ trades
9-  Limited dungeon

1 - Well if you have been checking ToS website last 7 days, they have banned thousands of botters and gold sellers. so its a good start =]

2 - If you play this game and complain about farm/ grind or drop rate, i have no idea why you are playing this game... i mean there are plenty of mmorpg that has loads of drop (D3) instant max lv (WoW). I mean if drop rate was bump up and farming and grinding was easy, wouldnt it sprout comments that game too easy, maxed level (nothing else to do) and too much drops = market saturation = oversupply = more complaining. so bear with it, Kinda thrilling if it drops a super rare orange recipe for you and you go OMG YESSSSS! i gonna rub it in my friends face!

drop rate is unfair thats life. unless you wanna play a game that gives u X item for X amt of time or mobs you did? I grinded a monster that dropped a bow i wanted, after being top 3 players killing it and i got zich, i sighed and moved on. its life.

I find the respawn rate reasonable, as you do need to know some class cant kill as fast as others, further more it would be pointless if there was near instant respwan rate, everyone would stand still and hit till kingdom come. learning how to farm and lure mobs is the idea, if there is a mass of players in the map, give other maps a try instead of just bunching your fist in fustration, instead try find new farming spots for yourself =] . STOP googling where is the best spot to farm! jeeze explore and learn!

UPDATE - at higher levels i know you will feel the squeeze, but thats why socializing is so impt in a MMO rpg.. get a team and farm tgt =] and ks others who dare to invade! do missions!

Lastly they even give u exp cards! its like cheating =x

3 - To be honest if you hate kser, you wont enjoy much of this game, I remember RO it was practically the norm to taut rivals by killstealing, leading to guild wars and pvp and trashtalkinig, it was really fun! i got the bad end of the stick a few times, but if you do not like killsteal, i think GUILDWARS 2 is a really fun game with zero ks element.

i mean i know maybe people work and study and have 2 hours of play time a day, if thats the case, get to know friends, party up and KS back! stop soloign too much or well you know you can just play...

gasp Archer  -.-

4 - Well you know there is a option to hide the bar on top and in your chat box right? They server splits have come, so you will see more of your native language. And alot of gold sellers spammers has been banned <3

5 - The game has came far and has been working hard to fix bugs, though more springs up at times, [dc at dungeon] i do have to say IMC has been doing a fair job at compensating us and trying to make our gameplay enjoyable! though they have to give us more time before kicking us out for urgent maintance sometimes =x

6 - firstly i believe classes are not balanced too, but to be honest why do you want it be? i mean its fun punishing players who randomly learn skill and classes. I feel this is INTENDED TO MAKE SOME PEOPLE to put in effort in building thier characters. If you want cookie cutter builds, go ahead, but in my experience, the best class builds for pvp are seldom shared. THOSE PLAYERS earned it and experiment it and suffered for it..

JUST taking someone else build and then complaining for it shows lack of effort, it could be your decision to follow it blindly.

7 - to be honest if its purely for pve pay to win you would not notice too much of a difference as i would say tier 1 stat on such headgear is HP. so it doesnt affect u if the other dude has 2.4k hp on total 3 headgear unless you are trying to lure the mob to kill a afk dude.

In actual PVP. you are given stock items and no headgears boost are allowed. so i don see a problem with that. =x maybe gvg. If people pay to buy gold.. i mean its thier choice and its up to the IMC to ban gold sellers, i do not really see how they affect one's own game play unless you say every single item on market is bought and you never had a chance to get one. =x

8 - This is biggie for alot of players, but do consider as IMC giving people who play lesser a chance to earn some gold. imagine if market has no cap on how many things you can sell, its way too easy for botters and people who played alot to flood the market and push everything down. By capping the number of stuff you can sell, i feel gives more casual players a chance to have a niche market. Also IMC makes rare high lv recipe requiring low level items, giving lower level players a chance (eg mithril).

Update - token user can sell 10 items now, intertrade btw characters is free now

9- Now after some players are nitpicking at these aspects. i would go back to saying market saturation, with unlimited dungeon, wouldn't the game be totally unfair for people who can afford 2 hours a day? and wouldnt the items (BESIDE TALT) become more common and the silver will be clumped to players with 16 hours a day to play? maybe there is some middle ground but i do not see having unlimited dungeons as a good thing =x Plus

overall i mostly experience bots considering the negatives.

MY truest advice is  - its just a game.. for all the flaws, i enjoyed it greatly enough to sink 150 hours + into it. I feel most problems arise when people keep comparing other players and how they legally or illegaly exploit the system. i for once enjoy the game with my friends.

Its easy to get lost in jealously of how far and easy some cheat thier way through, but to be honest it does not affect how you play a game unless he is literally beside you ksing and trash talking you all the way. If you do get triggered  easily i might suggest to play in short bursts

To be totally honest with you, this game should not be available to the public in it's current state.
It is essentially still a BETA and I suspect that on 04/28/16, when it goes F2P, it will still be in a BETA stage.
Needless to say, there is a LOT of problems and issues with this game.
If you can think of an issue, it's here somewhere.

That said, despite all the problems, all the issues, all the frustrating bugs and more, this is still a really good MMO.
I can't recommend this to people who never played nor enjoyed Ragnarok Online or similar games. But those who did, should definitely give this a try at the very least.

To the developer, IMC GAMES.
Please take these reviews heavily into consideration. You have a gem in your hands. It just needs an aggresive polish.

reviewText:
TL;DR version - don't bother with this game. It's another cash-grab title that will become a ghost town in 1 year.

Here is a long list of problems with Tree of Savior:

1) You can't trade with other players. You read it right! You can't trade at all. The only way to trade with your friend, is if both of you purchase a 18$ token that allows trading for 30 days. And it has a limit of 30 trades per month! Sharing items to your alt character also decreases the trade count by 1.

2) You can't trade silver in a direct trade, even if you have Token. If your guildmate needs to borrow 100k silver really quickly to buy something from auction house, too bad you can't do him a favor!

3) You can only put 1 item in the auction house, the item takes a random time between 30 minutes and 2 hours to appear on the market, after you sell it there's 30% tax, and you need to wait over 2 days to retrieve silver from the market! If you have a token, you can put up 5 items at a time and the tax is reduced to 10%. There is another limitation to the market - the price at which you try to sell your item is adjusted by the system and there's nothing you can do about it.

4) IMC (game developer and publisher) did all of the trade/market restrictions supposedly to fight the RMT traders (goldsellers). It did absolutely nothing. Goldsellers are still littering the game. The real reason behind those changes was to force players to spend 18$ a month on a token.

5) As a result of the above, the market is a joke. If you enjoy a healthy marketplace, that's not what you'll find here. Playing the market to earn money is barely profitable because of the market's flaws. The market is bugged and can be exploited by malicious players.

6) You can't create a guild until you have reached rank 7, which is nearly the level cap of 280. For the whole game you can't be in a guild.

7) This game destroys the social aspects of interacting with other players. I'll make a short list:

a) When you make a party, you expect to be able to choose basic loot options. Not in this game. You can only choose Round Robin, Random or Pick-Up. If you play with random people, you can't trust them enough to have pick-up option enabled, because one of them will most likely steal all the loot. There is no class-restriction when looting, no dice-roll system, no greed/need system, no bid system like in B&S. Pray to RNJesus that you get the drops that you need.

b) When you're leveling with a friend, you can't trade without a Token. Even if you buy that, you will be restricted to 30 trades per month. You'll run out of this limit in a week of playing together.

c) Market has so many limitations, it destroys the idea of healthy and vibrant economy. In this game, you'll think twice before putting anything on sale.

d) All the leveling/questing is easily soloable. An MMORPG is supposed to be a multiplayer game, where people feel the need to party up to clear the hard content. Here, the only times you'll need a party is for dungeons or for grinding spots that are heavily contested for.

e) The mob population is too small, there are not enough mobs for everyone on the map. There are not enough channels to accomodate all people. The spawn timer is between 2-5 minutes for almost all mobs! So 80% of the time, instead of fighting, you'll be running around trying to find mobs to kill.

f) Dungeons have a limit entry of 2 times per day. And this limit entry is shared between all dungeons. So, if you do dungeon A 2 times today, you can't enter dungeon B or C. If you have a token, that's 3 entries per day.

g) You can't queue to a dungeon if you're in a party. If you enter a dungeon in a pre-made party, you only get 450% exp bonus. If you queue solo, you get 600% bonus. You either go with people you know and get punished for that, or you queue with random people who probably have no idea how to play.

f) Same thing with PvP - you can't queue if you made a premade party. Want to play PvP together with a friend? Sorry, you can't.

8) The game is, not very advanced in terms of graphical effects and shouldn't be very demanding on your PC. At least in theory. You'll need a high-end PC to enjoy a framerate exceeding 50 fps.

9) You will be getting random screen stuttering all the time. If you play in a party, sound begins to stutter when 5 people are hitting one boss at the same time. It's painful to hear.

10) Dungeons give way too much exp. Consequently, many players will just do their daily runs and log off because grinding on the fields isn't very efficient exp-wise.

11) The issues with lag/latency/server instability are very bad. I've played many MMORPG in the past, some of them right from day 1, but never experienced something like this. On the first day, the only way to login was to select a server, click Enter" button
date: then patiently wait for 2-3 minutes to log in. If during that time
hoursPlayed: you are put right at the end of the queue. There was no way of figuring it out that you're supposed to wait patiently for 2-3 minutes to log in. Most players would just assume that the login is broken and keep clicking on the "Enter" button every few seconds.\nIf you managed to log in
voteText: there were queues everywhere
helpfulPercent: that could take up to 2 hours or more. It persisted for more than 2 days. The lag during combat was tolerable. But
votesHelpful: the lag manifests if you want to talk to NPCs or use an item. You can't even pick-up drops from mobs instantly
votesTotal: it takes over 10 seconds for them to be picked up. When walking around
votesFunny: you will be randomly teleported back because of the server issues.\n\n12) There is little to none communication with IMC or their Staff. They don't respond to people constantly complaining about the problems I mention in this review. Some of those problems have existed in the game since the first closed beta

column17: and guess what? It's never been fixed.\n\n13) The game is tending towards being a cash-grab product. You are blocked from basic functions like trading with other players if you don't pay. In KR

reviewText:
Where do I start?

I have played in each and every international beta released starting in August.

Many things have changed since then be it level caps, zones, mechanics, or server side XP.
That being said I have put nearly 800 hours between the beta releases and the current early access and I plan to put many more.

If you are reading this then its likely you saw the game has mixed" reviews right now. I implore you to actually go through the list of reviews and funnel out the massive amount of thumbs down by people who have played the game for absolutely no time considering this is an MMO. There are also people who are down voting it simply based on a mechanic they dislike rather than giving it a proper review.

Now onto the actual game review. I am currently around level 230 with the current cap being 280. I suggest you do research into the type of character you wish to build and the paths it will take.

Currently there are quest available till around level 235 and from that point on you will actually need to really grind if you wish to reach the maximum level. If you do research you will find you can reach level 200 without any grinding at all fairly easy(Don't waste cards).

At level 100 leveling gets easier as it opens up daily missions and quest which scale to your level.

The game offers controller support
date:
keyboard support and mouse support. However I will say controller support needs to be refined a bit more to allow key mapping.

Graphical settings are fairly basic but they are now adding more to the game to help improve the experience of those who need them.

The musical score in this game is phenomenal and its fairly rare for most mmos to keep you wanting to keep the OST on rather than mute it and listen to your own music.

The game offers a wide variety of classes to play each with unique skills to make use of.

While you could very well solo in this game up to a certain point with no issues its highly recommended you try and party though content. Not only will you get through the content faster but leveling will be faster and its great to make friends at the same time.

A cash shop does exist but as of right now 4/26/2016 its in no way P2W which is great.


Cons -

The biggest con of the game currently is that there are quite a few restrictions which are getting worked on due to player feedback. I don't however believe this game deserves a bad review because of them which if you notice is where the majority of the thumbs down come from.

Bots are a problem in every mmo and just like those this game will have bots they are however publicly announcing bot bans every day and added a system so players can report the bots they see.


All in all I highly recommend if you want a new mmo to try this game out and then form your own opinion afterward on if its worth your time or not."

reviewText:
The game has awesome art and is relaxing to look at while playing. The music is great too and the number of classes/builds is huge. I haven't found it particularly grindy so far, I've just been doing quests.

The people moaning about lag and silver spammers are talking about the first week of early access. What do you expect? Happens to all MMO's at launch. The lag has significantly improved already & IMC put a level restriction on Megaphones (which the community asked for). The spam in global is mostly gone now. Also the servers are all in the US at the moment, the EU server will be relocated to Europe when F2P starts.

As for talk of the premium aspects, 30 day subscription tokens can be purchased  in the AH for in-game currency. At the current prices in silver, you can easily obtain enough silver by killing mobs as you quest, even at low levels.

Edit: It's just been announced that due to player feedback the 1:1 trade restriction for non-token players is being removed and a bot report function added.

reviewText:
Lots of people are comparing this game to Ragnarok Online (RO), but Tree of Savior is actually more similar to another famous IMC game, Granado Espada (GE). The same group of people worked on all three games, and it shows.

While its art and class design is meant to invoke RO, the teams system, item shop, megaphones, EXP cards, map design, audio, and even costumes are basically copied from GE.

The Good:
Visually beautiful
Large map with many zones and assets
Very content rich for a brand new MMO
Music by the legendary soundTemP and friends (same composers for RO and GE)
Nostalgia.
The Bad:
Too much stuff locked behind microtransactions. Without a paid token, there are heavy restrictions on trading.
Bots and gold sellers. Every game has a few, but it's an all-out infestation here. IMC isn't even trying to stop them.
Iffy controls. The keyboard system is not accurate or fast enough for PVP, and the mouse system is not as fluid or responsive as say, Diablo 3.
Unpolished. Problems with hitboxes, bugged quests, invisible walls, etc.
Unsuitable music. The throbbing techno was an good choice for the grimy world of GE, but not here. The RO soundtrack alternated between light ambiance and memorable themes, which would've suited ToS better.
The Misunderstood:
Questing may seem linear at first, but becomes more open world later on. The map progression system is identical to GE, but not fully open world like RO.
Grindy for a modern day MMO. Roughly as grindy as GE, but thankfully nowhere as grindy as RO. Some people like this, some people don't.
The class system feels overwhelming at first, but it's designed to create highly specialized characters that provide a niche service to parties or the entire community (crafting, upgrading, etc). This is similar to RO, and indeed many skill concepts in ToS are borrowed from RO/GE. But due to the grinding, there needs to be easier/cheaper ways to reset characters.
Conclusion:
As with RO and GE, Tree of Savior was created by a talented team with big ambitions, powerful artistic vision, but poor quality control. These are the type of creative folks who have great ideas, but don't know how to package or deliver their product professionally. This has resulted in rough launches and patchwork gameplay (especially questing) during the early days of all three games.

That being said, RO and GE both went on to be very successful MMOs. If there is one thing that could doom ToS, it's the excessive restrictions for non-premium players.

Despite its shortcomings, the game is clearly a labor of love with much content to explore. If out of nothing but nostalgia, I would still recommend giving Tree of Savior a try.
voteText: 212 of 349 people (61%) found this review helpful 14 people found this review funny

reviewText:
EDIT: Since I wrote this review, IMC has announced they are going to allow users in Klaipeda and Orsha to transfer to a new SA server. Also, they are adjusting prices for in-game items fairly according to each server after the migration to fix any advantage a player from a different region may have due to the different rates of inflation around the globe. This is why 'Fractured Community' is crossed out below, as the developers have done all they can to solve this problem short of forcing people out of their servers.

Let me start by saying Tree of Savior has its flaws. They are as follows:
Problems with bots which the development team is aware of. Already they have patched in a bot report system and I assume there are more fixes in the works.
Bugs which are plenty, however not game breaking. There are some oddities in the gameplay of some of my friends who have played where sprint does not function properly. There are cosmetic bugs to be found here and there, however I haven't found anything in my own experience of playing around 22 hours that was game breaking.
Server lag is probably the biggest issue with the game to-date. Even in its current state with only 'founder' access to the game there are many times when the servers are populated to the point of gameplay becoming affected. Sometimes lag is to the point where you can't kill an enemy until it settles down. One can only hope they do something to improve the performance of the servers.
Framerate can drop below 60fps in heavily populated areas even on a good computer. Running the game on a GTX 980 I did not expect to experience any visual lag in a game that emulates a 2.5D appearance. In the big cities of Orsha and Klaipeda though you will certainly drop below 60fps and see noticeable frame drops.
Fractured Community on the server I play on, Orsha. While I have nothing against my brothers and sisters in Brazil, there are too many Portugeuse-only speakers on Orsha for an English-only speaker to become very invested in the community. While the title of the game on Steam says it is the English version of Tree of Savior, it is obvious that the Brazilian community deserves their own server.
Free players can't do much in the current version of ToS. You can't trade or put up more than 1 item on the marketplace at a time. Of course the developers need to make money...so for now this is their solution to incentivize buying premium for the game. The developers have said they are looking for a way to allow free players to trade, however you can't help but think it will be limited in some way. Only time will tell what economic decisions the devs will have to make with the game. Thus is the nature of F2P.
Character customization is weak. You can choose male or female, however there are limited options for both genders.
So what is there to like about Tree of Savior?
Combat is probably the biggest pro in Tree of Savior. The action combat in the game is satisfying. Every wave of enemies you kill feels like a blast of progression towards the next level. Each class in the game plays a unique style and takes advantage of spatial awareness in the action combat. Boss battles utilize this very same aspect of the game. If you see a boss charging up an attack, don't just stand and auto-attack, run!
Controls feel old-school and backwards at first (I mean arrow keys to control...what is this 1993?!), but once you understand how to access the game's different menus through your function keys and get familiar with moving around it all feels very intuitive. Even something as simple as teleporting to a completed quest is made easy with just a quick press of backspace. It's nice how almost everything in the game able to be controlled without lifting your hands from your keyboard.
Visuals are great in Tree of Savior. Everything is rendered in 3D, but the game is textured and lit in such a way that you could swear you're looking at the 2.5D Ragnarok Online. It's a beautiful effect, and it makes exploring more enjoyable. Each area in the game has a unique environment and flora. This is a game whose graphics have character. You will dangerously wander into higher level areas if you don't keep your eyes on the road.
Interface is good. It is nothing revolutionary but everything is where you would expect it to be. All your menus are accessed through your function keys, F1-F12. This is unique for an MMO where 'I' is typically your inventory, 'E' will access your equipment, etc. It takes some time to get used to, but it's actually a relief with the action gameplay to have all your menu buttons out of the way of an accidental keystroke.
Class diversity is wide ranging. You can play any style you want with 80 possible class combinations. Some classes can advance to higher levels, or 'circles'. Some classes appear to have limited usefulness in the current version of the game, so do your research before dedicating yourself to a particular line of classes. That being said, no class is the wrong choice as long as you know what is and is not recommended for that particular class. Again, do some basic research on the many guides and manuals written by the community and make your own informed decision of how you want to play the game. EDIT:A note on classes...while there are 80 different choices of classes in Tree of Savior, not all of them are a viable option. In fact, many of the circle 3 classes are weak and don't provide any useful skills. It is worthy to note as well that only one or two stats per class are really useful, for instance a swordsman player set on going Hoplite may allocate stats to only STR, STR and DEX, or STR and CON. At the end of the day whatever class you choose know that ToS is a game about damage and your choices have to reflect that to succeed. Thank you Indeed for contributing your insight in the comments.
The Verdict
Tree of Savior is a fun little F2P MMO. In a lot of ways it feels like a Frankenstein cross-over between Maplestory, Ragnarok Online and an action RPG game like Torchlight. There are plenty of flaws in this early localization of the game, however the flaws that do exist are not game breaking and have not stopped me from enjoying the game 22 hours in and counting. It is a visually impressive game that offers satisfying combat, tight controls, and a large number of classes to choose from. Free players are extremely limited, character customization is weak, there is a fractured community of different languages, plus bugs and server lag are plenty...but to me these are lesser cons to the powerful pros of the game. I recommend Tree of Savior for someone looking for a different take on MMO combat.

reviewText:
:: Telsial server ::

Positive opinions:
- Explorative, beautiful art and music.
- The party stays intact even if everyone goes offline, acts like a chat channel for friends.
- Each account takes up one slot of a party, removing the need to join the same party with sub characters.
- Chat log is preserved even after logging out.
- Many collection and achievements to be completed, including map exploration and finding chests.
- The variety of classes is indeed interesting, makes it challenging to create a build that is up to one's satisfaction.


Negative opinions:
- Too crowded, too many killsteals.
- Each map has a number of channels of its own, some maps are small and have too few channels.
- Doing quests that requiring killing mobs is like going to an extremely crowded marketplace.
- Hackers and bots running all over the game, even during this early access period.
- Bad community. Most of the players are rude and use vulgarities unnecessarily.
- Classes that deals less damage seems to gain less loots from killing a monster with other players.


Overall, this game may fare well as a single player game, or as a co-op game for smaller groups of friends.

reviewText:
-Trading restrictions*update*. IMC has allow 1:1 trading regardless of Token status. BUT, if a token user engaged trading with a non-token counterpart, items will be rendered untradable. If you're planning to execute  1:1 trading, remember to check if the other party has a Token icon/buff on their character info. Unless items weren't meant to re-trade after receiving then this shouldn't be an issue.

- Such trading system does not hinder RMT nor  gold sellers from completing their deal. In the end, playerbase are paying a huge price for trading limitation.

- Unable to transfer silver or crafting materials to your alts. Crafting mats purchased from Market can't be transferred via Team Storage even if you're on Token(Subscription)

- Maximum of 1 concurrent listing on the Market and 10 for Tokens.

- 48 Hour wait to receive in-game currency after an item listed were purchased.

- Daily limit of 2 entry per instances/missions. 3 for players who purchased Token.

- No tentative pricing structure on tokens but rumoured to be around USD 18. No info given if it is  a 30 or 60 day token with the rumoured pricing.

-Terrible optimisation with stuttering and flickering(on fog/mist/water related textures). Low frame rates also occur during Guild vs Guild and world bosses hunting.

-Servers couldn't cope with the surge of players hence experiencing lag spikes all over.

- Due to an exploit, players were able to claim in game items from Founder's Pack without the need to pay. (by forfieting payments made to Steam). Hence, Marketplace is pretty much flooded with Tokens at the moment.

-IMC did took an effort to combat it by disabling Marketplace and 1:1 trades up to 72 hours for newly created teams.(That was after more than 10 days after the exploit went viral)

-Abundant of bots and script kiddies(teleport, speed, AOE hacks etc etc)

-Public group finder(dungeons/missions) were broken from time to time. Unable to zone into dungeon after a full group has been made. Premade groups are fine(server and hour dependant). All you could do is wait till you're able to zone in. High population servers on peak hours are affecting premade groups from joining any instancesMax Instance Count).

-Issues with 'Commander Load Fail'. Unable to zone into instance during matchmaking. Hence disconnect and returned to login screen. At times unable to log in after character selection screen(Lodge).

-If you're planning to engage world bosses kindly refer to this link: https://forum.treeofsavior.com/t/world-bosses-and-what-you-should-know-approaching-them/219901

-Blatanly joining without a decent amount of DPS will not net you any loot(Cube). Chance for loot depends on amount of damage done.

-Lack of communications with playerbase on forums.

- Server instability such as Varena (Sea) and Silute(SA) preventing players from proceeding with dungeon runs or logging on. Most of the players are facing high queue times after F2P officially launched.

- Stat and Class circle reset are not available in cash shops. If you're planning to play any class, please do some research over at reddit/tosbase/Class Ranks on official forum.

-F2P launched but TP isn't available for purchase at the moment. Instead IMC releasing a 'Beginner's Pack' & 'Veteran's Pack which are priced above than average.

- If you're interetested to know the current state of the game, a playyer who loved the game so much has decided to voice out in this link. https://forum.treeofsavior.com/t/i-love-tree-of-savior-i-am-leaving-tree-of-savior/275395/46

reviewText:
20-word Summary: Experiences vary from server to server, and the game is very unpolished. Play only if you played RO.

10/10 for Art, Style and Concept
4/10 for Implementation and Gameplay

Pros:
Numerous Classes - very versatile builds. (Of course, there are meta builds, and not-so-great builds. But you'll really have to try in order to screw-up your builds.)
Retro RO-style gameplay given an update.
Gorgeous Art
Loads of content, especially from Level 100 onwards. (Completing the daily dungeons, missions, party quests and solo repeatable quests can easily take an entire day. Especially if you timed it around the daily resets.)
Grinding is minimal if you pace your exp card usage correctly, and do the daily content. (Not necessarily on a daily basis. :D)
Cons:
Bugs, bugs, and more bugs. Especially if you're on the South American server.
Private messaging system is broken - Get every player you wish to play with often on Discord/Telegram/Kik/Skype/etc as soon as you can.
Bots and RMTs everywhere - they need to implement captchas and/or more efficient ways for players to report the bots/RMTs.
Trade restrictions - implemented to deter bots/RMT and failing in every way possible.
Personal bug point #1 - They don't have warp points for every map and only the swordsman class has dash. It takes clerics ages to get somewhere. Having to run through 2-3 maps each time for a repeatable quest is pretty ridiculous.
Personal bug point #2 - Mouse control mode is glitchy. :x
Some servers are totally overpopulated, and it's sometimes impossible to get into dungeons. #TreeofSpacebar
No Stat resets! - Hope you don't cry every time you re-roll. (*Some* players got the stat reset potion as part of the early founders' DLC, but there's no sign of IMC introducing the reset potions.)
Guild system is terrible.
I play this because:
1) I played RO, and *love* the visuals.
2) I'm not affected by most of the bugs/problems that others face. Some inconveniences yes, but that's about it.

But for others...? Take your chances if you wish.

reviewText:
I really wanted to love this game, but I just can't do it.  There are so many things wrong with this game.  I played this game since head start and have a level 230 (280 is the max level you can be) with a bunch of alts.  I have been through so many annoyances in this game and I'll list them out:

-Trading system is terrible.  You cannot trade silver for items or give silver to friends.
-So many quest bugs.  I'm still stuck on a low level story quest because it won't let me and many others to click on the NPC.  It has been posted on the forums, but IMC doesn't acknowledge it and the bug is still around.
-Auction house is terrible.  Takes 30 minutes to 2 hours for your item to be posted on the auction house.  If your item sells it will take 48 hours to get the money!
-Instance drops are very low.  I have done this one low level instance every day for 3 weeks and still haven't received the two items I've been looking for.
-Buggy skills and clunky fighting!  The fighting isn't smooth in this game at all.  The skills feel clunky and awkward.  Playing a wizard class I often find that my skill doesn't go off when it's suppose to.  For example, when I cast hail the casting bar will charge up and my character will do the animation at the end to cast, but hail never goes off and my character is frozen for a second or two.  I then have to re-cast it.  Also, some times the ground skills won't go to the place you want them to be.  For example, your cursor can be on a monster and your character can be facing the monster, but when you use your skill it gets placed somwhere completely different.
-Lag!  If you enter a map with a lot of people you will get lag.  If you fight a world boss with other people around you will get lag.  This happens to everyone and it doesn't matter if you have the best computer in the world and the fastest internet.
-Long loading screens.  Lots of people experience long loading screens in this game and there are tons of loading screens in this game.  The loading screens take a very long time when entering a populated area like the main city.  One time I had to wait 5+ minutes.

Now I will talk about PvP...  To get your pvp fix in this game you'll need to find another guild's tower which can be anywhere on any field map.  Once you find the tower, your guild leader has to declare war.  It takes an hour for the war" to start.  Once it starts
date: you can pvp the other guild for 7 days and you can kill their tower.  There is no reward for killing the tower and there is no reward for any thing.  There's also no rank system.  It doesn't tell you who got how many kills and it doesn't keep track how many GvG battles your guild has won.  Nothing.  The tower will eventually get destroyed no matter how well you defend it in the beginning because no one can defend the tower 24/7.  Some times an announcement will go up if you kill the other guild's tower so the whole server can see it and some times the announcement never happens because the game is buggy like that.  Some times you can heal your tower and some times it bugs out and won't let you heal it so the enemy guild can just slowly kill it with one hit here and there no matter how well your defending it.  Also
recommended:
when your fighting people they can just switch channels in the middle of the fight easily or drop guild tag in the middle of the war so they don't have to worry about PK.  There's no point having a tower up all the time.  The only real use out of it is to level your guild up so you can add more spots.  Guilds start off small with only 30 spaces for people.  You can use talts to level up your guild by clicking on the tower and it takes a lot of talts.  That's the only real reason to have a tower up.

Now I've been trying to put up with all these annoyances I've listed.  But I'm going to be quitting now after reading the recent patch notes...

1) Guild Related
A. The guild master will be able to set the guild to 'Neutral' by checking the [Declare Neutrality] option on the Guild UI.
B. Guilds may not declare war on other guilds or have other guilds declare war while 'Neutral'.
C. It is not possible to Declare Neutrality during war.
D. Neutrality will be maintained until manually changed by the guild master.
E. Only guild masters are able to change the 'Neutral' state of the guild.
F. 7 days must pass in order to change the guild status from 'Neutral'.
G. Guild masters are now able to declare war on up to 3 guilds at once.

The little bit of PvP that was in the game is now ruined for me and my guild.  It's already hard to find PvP and this now will make it pretty much impossible.  It basically says everyone can put their towers up without a care in the world because they can choose to be neutral thus never have to participate in this game's sad excuse of GvG.  I was really hoping they would have a system like War of Emperium in Ragnarok Online

reviewText:
I've played little bit on this game.

Let's talk about the good parts.

PRO:
-Nice graphics (I love the design)
-Awesome soundtrack
-Cool class system


Now the bads:

CONS:
-NO MATTER your computer, you will LAG / FREEZE/ FPS DROP. Check the official forum about that. This game IS NOT OPTIMZED AT ALL;
-BOT ?!  Well I'm pretty used to see bots and gold spammers in MMORPGs, it's a common issue. But IMC is using the wrong method to prevent them from botting / selling gold. (They are basically restraining legit players interactions)
-DO NOT PLAY SWORDMAN UNLESS YOU ARE GOING FULL TANK. Basically swordsman class have (should have) the highest HP (Hello wizard skill that give more HP than a swordsman) BUT THEY ARE WAYYYYYYY TOO FAR IN THE DAMAGE / DPS LEADERBOARD. I mean even if you are going FULL DAMAGE SUBCLASS, you will stil way behind than a wizard that took few supports subclass and you will be at the same level as a Cleric with damage subclass.
So play Archer (Best DPS by far), Wizard (second highest DPS with tons of CC) or Cleric. Forget swordsman (my most preferred class in any MMORPGs RIP)
-Market is broken too (For gold selling prevention, that's what IMC said, but it's just restraining legit players basically)
-Cannot trade silver (Again for gold sellers)
-Talt (If you play the game you will understand)
-PvP ? No balance between classes, forget it

Anyway, You can try the F2P if you want. But for now my review is negative since the actual state of the game is broken.

reviewText:
I bought into the RO nostalgia hype but felt ready to quit this past weekend.  I purchased Founder's Pack 2 around the release date, spent ~135 hours on the game and leveled up 4 characters to 68, 70, 74, and 109.  As I made my way through mage tower 2f on my ranger, I ultimately had a lonely realization that this game is a waste of my time.

Sure, I can plow through tons of mobs with minimal strategy, but I did the same things in all the other maps.  I rarely come across other people but when I do there's of course there's no interaction as we're racing to get through content.  Seeing bots on field maps just discourages me even more because I'm wasting my time sitting at the computer while others automate this hamster wheel process.

My token just expired and I just simply don't enjoy the idea of the diminished results from my time invested.  I could use my TP to buy a new token but I'd just be prolonging the inevitable.

The game just isn't exciting or compelling enough for me to continue.  I don't get satisfaction from facerolling through quest bosses, grinding for collections, or racing through boring dungeon runs and being rewarded with amazing talt or crappy boss cards.  After achieving the first few ranks it's a long way to experience new skills or classes.  There's no pvp at my level that I'm aware of. I like using a DS4 controller but even with target lock activated it's not really locked and it tries selecting mobs outside of my attack range as another mob is a couple steps away from me.

Bottom line is that there's just too much time required to invest for what I consider lousy rewards.  How many hours does it take for 1 meaningless stat point?  More than I'd like to know, that's for sure.  I really wanted to enjoy this like I did with RO, but the fun factor fell off very quickly.

reviewText:
Lets be clear about something.
This game no matter what people will say it's STILL in development, with weekly updates and hotfixes every time they are possible.
This game is actually very enjoyable, just need polishing and a lot of love from the community. We've been expecting this game since a lot of time already. Which makes us all impatient on the appearance of problems we never heard on the making.
But this game has at most 2 week on the market (being hitted quite hard with bricks for details that CAN be fixed) So be patient before picking up the torches and hop on the hate train...
On to the all powerful list of pros and cos...

PROS:

+The game enjoys of a great variety of classess and internal builds, in which we can see for now that none are better than the next. What do i mean with this ? You can actually enjoy the game and feel useful with almost any kind of build you pick fancy (It's true that some might be more or less useful early on the game, but that's it)

+The soundtrack is simply amazing, passing from Techno, to Metal, to theme background music in a way you don't feel stuffed or bored with it. Which is ALWAYS a plus in games you're planning to be more than 1 hour a day.

+The gameplay actually feels refreshing, having a MMO without point and click, as well as having something of a response with you to actually avoid things, instead of just a stat calculation feels very nice.

+The game is adapted for a controller support as well as mouse and keyboard

+The content of the game is actually overwhelming, and we're only seeing the tip of the iceberg for now.

+The game feels relaxing and enjoyable, you're hooked to continue playing without actually feel exausted for it.

CONS:

-Talking the elephanth in the room here, the trade system... It's true that the Devs are doing what they feel best to fight against the Gold sellers in game... But the messures they are taking might backfire pretty soon, once they have the general population of the game without access to general features such as trade.

-There is a lack of visual customizations on the game, basically everyone feels exactly as the neighborg, there is no way to add a personal touch to a character besides a really small headgear (I pressume this content would be added later on, but they are lacking a bit on that for now).

-The Guild system is depending on a specific class to actually have it. I would have been fine for so called class (The Templar) would have beneficts on the momment of making a guild, or even managing it. But if you want to make a guild you have to take one of the few slots of your tree, reach rank 7 and then make a selection of a virtually useless class beyond just making the guild itself.


This is just a small compilation of points. I could continue forever just pointing every small thing, but here is addressed almost in total of what this game is without entering in the issues any normal MMORPG has.

Takes to add that the Devs are already adressing the issue of the economy, trade system and Team storage (which is the name for the account system you handle)

reviewText:
I am one of the most tolerant gamers you will ever meet. I can put up with a great many problems, and it takes a LOT to rattle me or get me upset enough to start complaining or bashing a company beyond a few jokes cracked here and there.

Having said those three things, and having put more than 190 hours into a game that I still do love, and still feel offers an amazing gameplay experience, with today's patch, I can't possibly continue to ignore what's going on here.

IMC you have done all of this:

1) Implement absurd restrictions to try and stop goldsellers and bots which only hurt real players without affecting goldsellers or bots in the slightest. Remember, goldsellers and bots exist for one purpose. To sell game currency, and to cheat their way to get it. They have unlimited time, effort and incentive to dedicate to circumventing your restrictions. Real players don't. They are frustrated. Many have or will simply quit.

2) Set out a release schedule for the game for 3 months staggered early access, and then listened to the community, going back on your plan and instead releasing a one month early access. The servers were not ready. Commander Load Fail crashed things left, right and center all through early access. Now, nearly two months post-launch, the lag is STILL intolerable with no end in sight. Stability isn't even a pipedream at this point, especially for the SEA and SA servers who can barely play the game, because in 2016, it seems that you have contracted with a company who can't even provide basic DDoS protection for your servers.

3) Announced free to play and then pushed it back two weeks because the game wasn't ready. You held multiple 24-hour maintenances to manually accomplish server transfers, a task that other game companies can automate in 10 minutes. When the game still wasn't ready you launched free to play anyway with even more devastating restrictions on free players. The free players came, and the servers crashed, spluttered and crawled again, even harder this time.

4) You launched free to play with all of the restrictions on free players, without any method to let those free players purchase TP to alleviate their restrictions. Now that you have finally released your absurdly overpriced one time DLC packs that BARELY include any TP, about a third of your potential customers have already quit.

5) During this entire time, you have refused to communicate with your player base on ANY level, including issuing cut and paste, irrelevant responses to support tickets, ignoring almost every keystone community issue as if they didn't exist, and issuing patch notes weekly for bug fixes that could have been accomplished by one intern working part time. Are you working on something big? Is there a reason that none of the kToS patches are being pushed here? Do you even PLAN to have the kToS patches applied here? Are you doing ANYTHING? We certainly don't know.

6) You take weekends off in a 24/7 customer service industry, leaving your product non-functional to entire subsets of your (paying) playerbase for DAYS at a time. In any other industry, your company would be bankrupt, shut down, your CEO and anyone in even the most remote position of authority would have their jobs nixed.

7) You FIRED your community manager for doing what she was supposed to do. And you replaced her with a soundless, emotionless void.

8) When paired with all of your other problems, including but not limited to:

bizarre, constant lag, disconnects, abilities misfiring, chat randomly being eaten by the ether (and while we're on the subject, the Orwellian chat filter that would be out of place in a children's game, much less one with blatant sexualization, panty shots and etc.) characters getting stuck, players being unable to get into dungeons, or being kicked out of dungeons once they are, the constant goldseller spam, bots camping high level grinding areas pushing legitimate parties out, world boss monopolization, lack of rewards for pvp, the glitchy market limit system, lack of meaningful rewards for pve (weeks with nothing but talt), class balance issues, item balance issues (arde dagger and cafrisun best in slot for 200 levels for -every- class without fail), the unsustainable economy (~10 high end items with absurdly luck based cost-enterprising, and the diminishing demand/cost for materials, creating a compelling reason for players to buy from goldsellers who are ever-present), poor translation, artificial grind walls and newbie traps, and glaring lack of social features (even a guild requires a rank 7 character to create), and many others I am probably forgetting:

It is clear how you feel about this game. Which is to say that you don't. You have no industry awareness whatsoever, and this is coming from someone who has played numerous F2P games in the past, from the likes of Nexon, Webzen, Aeria and etc., all companies who are notorious for their poor customer service. You somehow manage to project even less of a positive image than they do. Incredibly, this is the first time I have ever actually felt like I enjoyed playing a game more than the developers enjoy making and maintaining it.

So why with all of these issues have I continued to play, and why am I done now? Because no matter how many issues I think the game has, I can deal with them if I believe the developer cares and is working on fixing things. I played FFXIV (the original) which was one of the most poorly received MMOs EVER, because I still liked the core game, and because Square-Enix acknowledged their mistakes and decided to try and fix them.

With the release of these DLC packs for $30 and $35, it is apparent that you believe you deserve the cost of a AAA game for putting forth zero effort. You do not market. You do not improve server stability. You do not communicate with your players. You do not address major game issues. You can't figure out how to implement the purchase of your own cash shop currency. You can't hardly claim overhead worthy of those prices, because you have nothing to show for the fruits of your labor over the last two months. You simply give no ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about Tree of Savior, beyond hooking the 1% of whales who will pay any amount to rule the roost in a game that is 5% good game, 15% Nostalgia and 80% catastrophe.

So here you go, IMC. You want to know how to take a straw and break a camel's back, and alienate even a calm, loyal player Look at your own actions over the past 60 days.

I'm done, and whether or not the white knights left will rush to defend you against this post is of no concern to me, because I know that even they have their breaking point, and if I'm at this point, I'd imagine it isn't far off.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Do not bother with this game. It suffers from horrendously poor coding and lack of developers and employees who actually have a say in what happens to the game on the international release team.

Some issues include not being able to play many of the classes such as those which have cast bars or consume items to use skills because casting is slowed artificially by the poor network code. The skills will take 4-5 seconds longer to do anything even though their cast bars have been full, and in the case of item consumption requirements (most later classes and several early-mid classes), the skill wont cast until the server notices the item has been used (4-5 seconds longer again).

You can expect a 4-5 second delay when interacting with any objects/NPCs in the game as well by the way.

Oh, and some skills, such as Psychokino's Gravity Pole cause the game to crash, which means you won't be finding many parties as that class or others that are similarly broken (you think this is temporary? Go look up how long this gamebreaking issue has been allowed to exist).

Other classes have random incompatibilities with the mouse and keyboard (the two main play modes) control modes such as not being able to turn while using channeling skills in the mouse mode or auto-targetting objects like fireballs as an archer who can't hit them while in keyboard mode (so all your auto attacks fizzle).

Issues beyond coding include free to play players only being able to sell one item at a time on the auction house (at 30% cut), and ALL players (including paying members) having to wait 48 hours to retrieve any sale profits. Silver is otherwise untradable (directly), so players have already begun using materials as currency. Traded equipment and materials either lose potential or become untradable, and many items in the game are untradable to begin with (gems for example).

You have four character slots and there will NEVER be an option to change one of your job classes for any of the 7 ranks that exist for each (eventually will be 10+). If you go X1 - X2 - Y1 - Y2 - Z1 - Z2 - Z3, and any of X, Y, Z get nerfed or just didn't work out for you, you have to remake your character.

You cannot transfer between your own characters without a token (198 TP), and even if you pay for one you can only transfer ONE item at a time (you can expand to 2 for 200,000 silver). Your personal storage is limited to 50 and many items, such as gems, don't stack.

Your gems drop on death and they disappear RAPIDLY, so rapidly that the server lag can sometimes make it impossible to get back in time solely from load screen durations.

You get 5 FREE TP maximum, which can only be used for megaphones, soul crystals (revive on spot), and repair kits. You may as well buy the crystals to avoid gem loss, and you will have to turn off megaphone shout to avoid losing brain cells since everyone using it is begging or spamming nonsense (says a lot about the playerbase).

The main issue that got me was the lack of support when things go wrong, which they will. You will NOT receive useful responses or support on the forums or to your support tickets since there's barely anyone on the international ToS team that can help (they most likely can't even communicate with the developers).

Not convinced? This is a copy of support's reply to the second of two tickets (they skipped the first) some (long) while after their submission:

Hello Savior
date: \n\nThank you for contacting us. Unfortunately lost items or gems due to being dropped when dying in the field are not retrievable if left in the field for a couple of minutes. We advise that you put your gems in your storage for safe keeping
recommended: or use a Soul Crystals when you dies in the field to able to retrieve the dropped items immediately.\n\nIf you have any other concerns
hoursPlayed: please do contact us again.\n\nRegards
voteText:
Tree of Savior Support Team"

The support tickets were about dying while in load screens and dying while in cutscenes

reviewText:
Product received for free

As much as I'd like to recommend this game, I can't in its current state. I far exceed recommended specs yet still get horrid FPS issues even with the settings turned down. This game's optimization is one of the worst I've ever seen for it being in closed beta for as long as it has been.

I mean aside from the optimization issues, I'd really enjoy this game. To be blunt and to the point, it's what RO2 should have been--a more actiony Ragnarok Online. If they'd fix the optimization and get it to run proper, I'm sure I'd spend a lot more time in it. But until they do I'll be waiting. It just runs way too janky right now.

reviewText:
The game has very little to offer beyond longevity. There's no sense of community in the game. There's no zone-wide chat to cooperate with others, there's only global chat (which takes a consumable item to use) or party/guild chat.

As an MMO, it's a failure. The game doesn't rely on healers or tanks for dungeons and missions. Bosses simply get zerged while they mindlessly walk towards their aggro target and use AoE attacks. Healers sometimes can save you when potions are on cooldown, but generally they're unnecessary. Class balance is AWFUL and the AI is really bad, so if you play a pet class be ready for frustration.

Leveling goes up to 280 or so with stat points, skill points, and class progression that you cannot undo (some can be undone with microtransactions, but others cannot). Core gameplay consists of:

Questing - Standard uninteresting MMO fair with minimal rewards.
Exploring - Small reward for discovering 100% of a zone's map. Very difficult with the base UI, but mods make it less confusing.
Combat - Hit a few cooldown with 15-60 second cooldowns. Then procede to auto attack a bunch, even if you're a mage or priest. Then use a mana and/or health potion to continue. There's no challenge to be found at all.
Dungeons/Missions - kill a bunch of trash and then fight several bosses. This gives MUCH more Exp for the time invested than anything else you can do, yet it has a daily limit of 2/3 for each. Basically this is your daily quest."

The game is full of bots spamming their websites in town or in the global channel. Completing quests and grinding Exp can involve more waiting than killing between sitting at a bonfire for SP if you choose to and waiting for monsters to very slowly respawn. There's also the option to camp world bosses that spawn every ~4 hours

reviewText:
TREE OF SAVIOR IS ALL BUT... RESTRICTIONS, RESTRICTIONS, AND RESTRICTIONS

Ragnarok Online was my childhood game, when I found out about the release of this game I immediately bought the highest priced Founder Access without a second thought... after 2 weeks I immediately regretted my action.

1. Trade restrictions in this game is one of the most ridiculous one I've seen in my 15 years of gaming experiences, for the very reason that it is the first of its kind which actually caused trouble for my progression in-game as I tried to transfer materials from my main character to alternate (through storage slot temporarily enabled by premium subscription) only to find that some part of my materials are unable to transfer across. To make things worse, I then realized that it was now impossible for me to transfer back the materials from my alternate to my main. The game developer has justified their poorly implemented restrictions for the glorious purpose of stopping bots and gold sellers, and yet I see endless numbers of gold sellers bot-spamming ads in the main town everyday and bots running rampant in popular dungeons.

2. Unreasonably, or I should say, utterly stupid loot system with ridiculous drop rates for some items will make you totally feel like quitting the game at days when RNG doesn't work in your favour. To craft a mid-game equipment, the recipe required me to farm for 15 materials from a group of extremely weak monsters who spawn in very few numbers. Coupling with the fact that the drop rate for the said material is 0.75%, and general low spawn rate of certain monsters including this one, I have in fact attempted to farm for the material for hours and didn't get any at all.

3. While this game succeeded in emulating the fun experiences of old school mmorpgs, they have unfortunately also retained features from the past which are obsolete and unacceptable in modern mmorpgs. Not only that, they have also incorporated some of the most despised features of a modern mmorpgs - a premium subscription option which treats non-premium players like worthless garbage with further restrictions (such as no item transfer between characters of the same account) on top of the abundance of restrictions already in existence.

4. Server lag and instability, I don't even have to mention much here.

The game, being spirit successor of Ragnarok Online, attempted to emulate the old school" mmorpg format which many old fans including me really appreciated it much. Unfortunately many of the features from the older mmorpgs have become reprehensible in modern games such as the idea of making people grind for items with drop rate as low as 0.01%  from monsters which are slow to spawn and yield no exp gains. Worst of all
date: they have placed unreasonable restrictions on trading which would have helped to relax the overly stressful grinding of loots
recommended: for the very purpose which they still fail to achieve at the end of the day."
