reviewText:
A typical no substance Korean grinder with graphics that attempts to make you think it's going to be like a much more classic Korean grinder that had at least SOME substance. Don't be fooled, this is the formulaic follow the breadcrumbs quest MMO with an interesting visual style and pleasant music. This will only appeal to RO fans who played the game only for cute monsters and hats.

Also might I add that there is an item called a token that is basically required to play the game and function like a real player, this item expires monthly and costs $18, so essentially this game has a scrip higher than any of the AAA offerings. The primary issue with this VIP service is the ability to train two attributes at a time, the attribute system itself being one of the game's main flaws as it works of off mobile game style timers, obviously being able to have two of these going at once gives a player quite an advantage. Other perks include things you'd consider so basic that the idea of paying for them never even crossed your mind, such as trading between your characters.  Hair costumes have stat upgrades that function off of cash shop purchases as well.

Some may say that these things can be purchased with in-game currency, while this will be helpful to some invdividual players, it will also have a PROFOUND impact on the economy of the game. The wealth distribution will become very top heavy, VERY quickly.

reviewText:
While Tree of Savior has a lot of appeal on the outside, it's really just a turd covered with a thin layer of gold. Yeah the graphics look nice, the music is nice, and the choice of classes gives you the hope of endless possibilities but there is so much going wrong with this game it's hard to even start.

1.) Not noob friendly... If you do pick up this game make sure you put in the time to learn about classes, builds, and exp walls. I understand that no game should hold your hand, and thats how I like my games but many people end up wasting their time and end up rerolling. So study before you even make a character. Just a sidenote I had two of my buddies quit because they were just casuals and wanted to jump right into the game. I respect people who just want to jump right in and have some fun but this isn't that type of game.

2.) Yes there are a lot of bugs and lag issues pretty much at all times. It doesn't really matter how good your rig is. This game is not optimized to perform well.

3.) Yes there are always bot spammers selling gold etc. You can go back to a location a month later and find the same bots farming under some generic name like farmingbot128. I assume they use numbers just to show their dominance and persistence. It's probably their way of saying hahaha you can't get rid of me! lolololol#@!$"

4.) Trade/Market restricions. Well first off you are going to want a token if you plan on using the market. Hell I'd go as far to say you want a token to play this game. Back to the point you can't trade gold
date:
and your market will be limited to 1 item for sale with a 30% commission if your f2p... dat tax doe. As you can see the developers try very hard to limit the bots/goldsellers but it has only ended up hurting the players gaming experience.

5.) The Grind... The grinding aspect of this game is not meant for all. It is long and feels unrewarding. Expect to grind a lot at later levels 140-16* and at 200+. A tokken should heavily be considered if you don't have one. And Exp Tomes can really help you save time. Yes you have to spend money to reduce stress... this is a buy to win game.

6.) Dungeons and bosses feel lackluster. Dungeons just don't feel good to do as most people just rush bosses. There might as well not be any trash packs. On top of that magic mobs can really mess your day up if you aren't tanky enough and don't have a healer. You have to pray that you get matched with tank/healer if not premade. Most boss mechanics don't feel very challenging either. The tank/melee are the only ones that have to worry about boss mechanics most of the time while the range dps can stay safe away and just drool on their keyboards.

7.) Where is the PvP? Where is it! All guilds are now neutral and team battle should have been functional since release. Seriously where is team battle
recommended: is it ever going to exist? I mean these things are advertised in the game info. You may as well take that off because your just false advertising your game. Unreal\n\n8.) Imba Imba Imba... Imba everywhere. Do expect a handful of classes to be better than others. I don't advise going swords unless you plan on going full tank
hoursPlayed: or for a pvp build (cataphract). If you choose to be a dps swords you will hate yourself later on. As for me I hate myself because I made a cataphract for pure pvp.. no peltasta for tanking... And guess what there is no pvp for me to do even with being in a guild. No grind groups will want a swords without pelt

These guys don't address any issues or make any attemps to respond to the community at all. Posts by these guys are just a few sentences long and mostly just "we are sorry

reviewText:
You could have just copied Ragnarok Online, with a giant *open* world , where each map is large and has certain monsters that have a set strength where there is no set in stone zone level and dungeons are just another map no different to any other area with mobs, where you can level wherever you like or can without being forced along a linear questline with the premise of kill and get xp in a class system that is fun and makes sense and a combat system that is simple but actually works.

But nah, we only get the cute art style and the great soundtrack. Is that really the only thing they thought was worth taking from RO? Why do we still have sterotypical western MMO tropes seeping into eastern MMOs now as well as every single western MMO? Why do developers STILL think that to make a successful MMO you need some intricate combat system that will never be good, because MMO combat is never good, but it is better to make a boring combat system that works than a boring combat system that doesn't. Most of the classes in Ragnarok played by holding left click, Runescape had a combat system where you left click once and wait until the enemy died for crying out loud, but it worked, and those games were highly successful. And stop forcing sheep hearding, mandatory linear quests for god sake, give players the means to find out how to level on their own.

Anyway, it's basically RO with the entire gameplay system cut out of it to be replaced with ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, overused and boring modern MMO tropes that I listed above, plus a very very terrible version of the class system from RO.

The positives
-Art style
-Music

The negatives that I care about
-Ultra clunky keyboard/controller based movement/combat system with practically zero targeting and you feel you have little control over your abilities, highly sensitive to ping, feels horrid when you aren't close to the server. The choice of this movement and combat system in a RO-esque/top down view MMO is utterly bizzare, the fact this isn't point and click like Dofus, Wakfu, RO and other top down games I'll never be able to work out. Why did the developers feel they had to be totally different here, but copy tropes everywhere else?

-Zones are horrifically small and feel totally crowded, made worse by the fact mobs spawn clustered in portions of the already tiny zone rather than randomly placed, your quest area is potentially smaller than the screen.

-Mandatory linear questing. You linearly progress through the zones, the ones you pass through, you won't return to. There is absolutely no open world elements whatsoever, you cannot go anywhere you want when you start the game like you can in RO or many other games for that matter. Even WoW has more choice on where/how you level than this game. This is the worst part that makes the game totally different to RO, terrible and destined to be a failure. The modern obsession with this system is a plague and developers can't seem to work out that if you do this your game dies most of the time. Add this with the tiny zones and you get double the cancer. What if I told you that it is possible to make an MMO without quests, or have them as optional side quests or ways to unlock other things? Well you can and I hope to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• MMO developers realise this soon.

-Class/skill system is kind of like they wanted to make it similar to RO, but change it so it is unique. Cept it is super stupid because early classes have limited abilities and branch out into new and totally different ones that don't actually complement each other. You have to get bow skills as an archer but then you can eventually get skills for daggers, but when you have daggers, whats the point of the bow skills you just learned. Half the time the old skills are weak and redundant later anyway. I'm not sure why they added 5 billion different classes and grouped them under a mere 4 starting classes. RO had 6, and they branched off into two more, then never branched again, but the starting classes had skills relevant to the classes they turned into, ToS doesn't.

There's more issues but there's no point mentioning them because of the reasons above. And no this isn't a first day rant.

reviewText:
Please don't write a negative review on an MMO based around lag at launch. What MMO doesn't lag at launch? Come now...

That aside, I really enjoy this game. It's going to be compared to Ragnarok Online in a lot of ways and that comparison is justified. They have the same team making the music, the same original creator, and the same general gameplay ideas.

What makes ToS great is the beautiful Latvian aesthetic, cute characters, and amazing character building. It's a grinding MMO in the typical vein, but it's something more to so many of us. It's a nostalgic trip down memory lane, but amped up to 11.

The game has it's quirks, and bugs -- but what MMO doesn't? The game will only improve with time.

reviewText:
From my experience in the 2nd closed beta:

Pros:
+great art
+amazing class system, lots of customization
+combat is fun, and it has very satisfying sound effects (which makes the grinding feel a little bit better)
+beautifully done soundtrack
+supports controllers/game pad
+cool ranking system
+exploration system, and a lot of maps to explore
+hidden classes!
+guild pvp (although i've never done it)
+beautiful UI
+i really feel like there's more pros but i haven't played the game in a few months so i can't remember xD

Cons:
-limited character customization (all you can customize at character creation is the class and hair style :/)
-the restrictions placed on players who aren't buying tokens (premium service) every month are a little ridiculous lol
-$18 for a hair cut?!?!
-exp cards in cash shop (+30% exp for an hour), makes the game a little pay to win
-seriously wtf $18 for a single hair cut
-personally, i think the questing is kind of boring and typical
-very limited customization with clothes in general. to my knowledge, the only equipment that actually appears on your character in game is hats and costumes, but there aren't very many of these that are just fun to collect (especially costumes). even the cash shop costumes are lacking a bit. this is honestly my biggest negative point for this game because i really love customizing my character and making them look cool and unique.

The game also has a lot of grinding, but I wasn't sure which category to put that in since some people like grinding and others don't. I personally don't mind it.
Overall, I would definitely recommend this game (especially to people who like old school mmorpgs). It has its negatives, but it's a hell of a lot better than most other new mmos out there.

reviewText:
TL;DR This game can be good, and it might be good, but right now it's awful.

I want to like this game, but at this moment, I just can't.
The game is graphically beautiful and they really did well on the art and music direction.
However, these are the only good points about the game.
The frequent fps issues, the server issues, the ingame trade controversy are just a small bit that make the game unplayable.
The fps seems to randomly dip throughout the game, going from triple digits to single digits in a matter of seconds.
The server frequently has issues where one cannot connect, this can take minutes or even hours to finally login.
If you didn't buy any of the founder's packs past the $10 point, don't even bother cause you're not even going to get to play 100% of the game's features, because they locked the ingame trade, as well as using the team storage.
If that wasn't enough, here are some of the other problems that make this game just another MMO.
-Grind for hours to level once you run out of exp cards
-Combat is repetitive and unsatisfying due to the limited amount of skills in the early game
-There's already botters ingame after a week
-Overcrowded servers; runs on a channel system which can randomly change your channel upon entering a map.
-Goodluck trying to grind, when almost every map is crowded and mobs take longer than the heat-death-of-the-universe to spawn.
-The minimap is about as useful as a man's nipples when using it to look for your party members
-Fkn archers coming and clearing the mobs that you were just ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing killing, cause archers don't have to chase runnings monsters and deal massive damage
-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• archers
-Potential hackers(I say potential because I am not sure if they are really hackers, but there have been sightings of people hitting things across the map by attacking seemingly nothing in one location without moving for hours.)

Now granted, aside from the botters and the occasional (hacker)? the community is really lively at times. Moving through maps you will get the occasional greeting from random players, players asking for help, people who really want to interact with others, which is a great thing for an MMO to have.
Despite this, I cannot recommend this game to anyone right now. Just call this game Tree of Sh!t cause that's what it is, except atleast actual sh!t doesn't try to hide the fact that it is sh!t. Don't buy the founder's pack. There are 2 weeks left until this game goes free to play and a one month headstart does not amount to much with all these issues plaguing the game.

reviewText: This is the Secret of Mana arpg mmo I never knew I wanted until I played it randomly with a friend at f2p launch.  I've been completely hooked since.  Taking a quick break from leveling up to address some of the major complaints people have.  There's a very cool game here, it needs work yet but don't let the negative reviews make you miss out because there's something great about this game and I could see myself playing it for a long time.\n\n- Unique approach to trading.  This is a major complaint for a lot of people but I think it's great. Most of the complaints are from new players that tried to trade their wooden shields off to a friend and then to an alt and found out they couldn't. In the long term it should keep the games economy very healthy and empower grinders instead of flippers. Materials can only be traded once, all mats go from source > crafter no flipping possible.  This is amazing,  increases the value of farming mobs instead of playing auction house simulator.  Equipment can be flipped by premium users but everything has a potential" stat used for improving items
date:
and this stat gets reduced by 1 with every trade.  This means items become less valuable with every flip until they also become untradable when potential reaches zero.

- Bots.  Every free to play game has bots.  Every subscription game also has bots.  As long as wealthy westerners are willing to spend thousands of Euros / USD on their mmo characters every month there will be people in places where electricity is cheap making their living by botting MMOs.  This doesn't seem any worse in this game than any other free to play game I've played. Everything instanced is party based and any bots out in the world are very visible.  Anyone suggesting that the bots are worse here than anywhere else hasn't been paying attention to what has been happening in their MMOs for the last decade.  The trade restrictions do have a HUGE impact on what bots can accomplish despite what others are saying.

- Server problems / lag / fps issues.  This is a legit problem
recommended: but has already improved since I started.  There are some FPS issues still but IMC seems to be working on them.  Lag has noticeably reduced for me in the last week.\n\n- Elite players controlling high end content has been a complaint I've seen a lot.  So what? it's competitive PvE

reviewText:
This game is pretty fun.  I first read reviews and saw the first 70 or so were all negitive so i decided i was not going to play.  Then one of my buddies picked it up and got my curious.

This game is not complete.  There are only 7 tiers of job classes taking you to about 225 for the last one.  As far as i can tell, they do not plan to stop there and stuff will be added in the future.  That being said its very similiar to releasing a beta of the game.  That is not as bad as it sounds though.  The game is pretty solid with what it does have and gives you a pretty wide range of classes to play.  Thousands of different job combos for each of the 4 classes.  And different ways to play through the game.

In this game you can grind like a mad man, or you can do daily dungeons and quests and level multiple guys at the same time quite effectively, or you can quest.  If you quest, instead of getting the exp reward instantly they give you exp cards.  Those cards can be saved up and used to push you through tough levels for you class or however you want.  A neat and varried system.

I have a coin, but i can say that i played about a week without one and the difference it makes it pretty insane.  Can't really imagine playing without one ever again.  The coins unlock many features that are used to limit and frustrate you into supporting the game.  I'm not sure if this is the best tactic, but it got me to buy it.

The crafting, item upgrading, gems, cards and pets are all pretty well done.  Crafting is actually relevant for obtaining some of the best gears.  Upgrading makes almost all peices of gear better in some way.  Gems provide neat buffs depending on the peice and can be leveled up to provide bigger buffs.  I like these systems.

The worst part about this game is bots and how they are trying to handle them.  Atm bots are to a degree ruining certain farmable crafting materials prices by having them constantly farmed.  This sucks but it also makes those mats cheaper for those looking to buy instead of farm, but it makes the farming yourself harder.  The restrictions on trading and the AH can get pretty frustrating.  They were put in to stop bots, but not really working.  They are however semi frustrating to real humans.  All in all though, they have already patched and made quite a few of them better.... provided you are using a token.  The most frustrating part is that you can't move gold between your characters, and if you buy any item off the AH that has no potiential, it becomes bound to that character.  These are not that huge as far as negitive impacts go.

I've only had lag for 1 day.  It was the day they split servers.  Can't really say its an issue at all.


TL:DR
Its a solid start to a game with many many fun choices to explore and play out.  Bots suck, but aren't that big an issue atm.  Alot of the complaints i see are solved by supporting the game and getting an in game Token for premium features.  That doesn't mean its pay to win, just lowers frustration level with trade and item limitations.  Meaning if you don't have a Token you must be patient.

reviewText:
If you get over the fact that this is early access and the game is thus affected by a plethora of bugs, this game has a great foundation upon which to build a great MMO. Most of the complaints aren't against the game's design itself, but bugs, server issues and temporary solutions to problems. I'll list a few problems:
->Sometimes your character will be stuck in limbo because a map is unavailable or bugged, or they'll have something that stops their progress(usually fixed within a few days)
->Servers are laggy and unstable, which results in long spawn timers, a select few classes' skills being annoying to use and unplayability during rush hours.
->The translation is still being worked on and some quest text is missing.
->The leveling curve may be slightly off balance in some regions, requiring grinding or creative exploration to keep up with leveling.

Considering IMC has shown time and again they are dedicated to making this into a good game, they have my full support and I fully believe these problems will be fixed given enough time and support from the community.

Now for the pros:
->This game's class system is great in that it allows for creativity and different synergies, although you'll want to study your build before you jump into it.

->Partying is incredibly fun and satisfying, since you'll always feel you bring something to the table(unless you make a very specific solo build) and even if you're just grinding on the same spot the interaction between players keeps the gameplay interesting.

->The questing is really enjoyable in this game because you'll find yourself often gaining new abilities as you level, keeping the experience fresh throughout all of it. Unlike certain games, you won't learn your main combo at level 10 and repeat it until you're max level, as every so often you'll change classes and gain new abilities to play with.

->Although some will claim pay to win, I feel like there is nothing a paying player can buy that gives them an edge in PvP other than making money fast. If you don't mind other players leveling faster than you because they paid(and not affecting you at all), this game is really fair in it's real money use.

->You'll always have something to do in this game if you like the core gameplay, as there is almost limitless growth from just exploring new areas and obtaining difficult-to-get items from crafting. You don't reach max level fast and play dungeons for a year until the expansion: Leveling and growing is the main focus of the game and it's built to last a while.

->Not considering bugs, the game's combat is really fluid, exciting and unique. I feel like they did a great job when just running around killing monsters for no reason feels fun and I forget I had to keep questing.

->This game's music is absolutely lovable and I haven't opened my playlist once in all my time playing.

Some cons, so I don't seem biased:
->There is no monster tagging in this game, and some populated zones will have you frustrated from getting kill-stolen by people.

->A few rare quests seem to take so long for no reason, like the time I was boredly mining coal for a good 20 minutes.

->This game has a ton of bots and silver sellers. They mostly don't bother me as they're restricted to a few zones farming, but if you don't like that you'll be annoyed. Although I do believe IMC want to end this problem, their approaches so far have failed and I don't know who will end up winning the war. Ragnarok Online, often compared to this game, was basically bot land.

->It is possible to make bad, irreversible decisions with a character which may cause players to be frustrated in the late game if they didn't plan beforehand. I advise you to research the game or copy a well-rated build for your first character.

->If you're the PvP kind of person, I cannot guarantee this game will be balanced considering the ENORMOUS variety of builds and possibilities. In Ragnarok Online, a much simpler game, some classes were utterly useless while others had very specific, unfun niches. If you're expecting to play PvP your own way, expect to lose. Note that as this is still very early into the game I'm just guessing how it'll be, from experience.




Overall, this game is incredibly enjoyable and better the more friends you have. I see a great future for Tree of Savior and it's community, if IMC is capable of handling the launch issues they currently have.

reviewText:
So here's the short and the long.

The short: Tree of Savior is a RO-like MMO that, while very fun and very promising, has a bunch of issues at the moment. Play it if you want something fun, gorgeous and nostalgic, and are willing to put up with stupid translations, horrible servers, janky optimization and some F2P restrictions.

The long: Tree of Savior is fun. It has a great foundation. In many ways this is like Ragnarok Online but it stands enough on its own to not seem like a simple clone. There are 80 classes, hundreds of levels, tons of zones, gorgeous music and visuals, lots of cute ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to collect and wear, so on and so forth. But it suffers a major problem. Its creator (IMC) is Korean, and its creator is new to the MMO field. This means that there are a lot of cultural disconnects where Korean players enjoy playing one way and Western players enjoy another way, and there are a lot of rookie mistakes, like thinking hiding global chat behind a paywall or prohibiting trade to premium players would stop gold-selling (it didn't). The servers are total ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and suffer from constant lag spikes, crashes, and rubberbanding. Luckily, IMC does seem to care. They've made changes quickly during the early-access based on our feedback, and they've given us Premium items (like exp tomes and enchant scrolls) as an apology for the issues. To me, this is huge, because they could just as easily have said Eh
recommended: all MMOs have that now" and ignored us. So if you're willing to put up with that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• for probably 1-2 more months while they hammer out the bugs
hoursPlayed: I think it's a great game with a great foundation and you'll have a lot of fun with it.\n\nAlso if you can read Korean and write with at least a 3rd grade English level

reviewText:
Tree Of Savior is far from perfect, and it certainly isn't revolutionary, but it is unmistakably a labor borne of love with great potential overshadowed by the realities of modern MMO business.

It's self-deception to claim TOS isn't targeted at players of Ragnarok Online, moreso to claim that said players, like myself, didn't fall for it, hook, bait, and sinker. The game's primary billing is its art style and music, crafted under the direction of Kim Hakkyu, who originally worked on RO and here proves he had a heavy hand in the uniquely charming, colorful world that continues to draw players both old and new into the RO habit regardless of all the gameplay flaws of that ancient work.

In TOS, that vision comes alive on the wings of modern MMO design. Instead of slaying your PC to load in HD physics-enabled 3D models with a billion variables for weight, scale, facial features, decal textures and hair morphs, TOS presents a clean, tightly-designed visual aesthetic that at once pays homage to and surpasses the charm of RO. Every scene looks like it came straight out of a storybook, filled in with richly colored illustrated environments and greeted by distinct-looking characters in anime style.

When you aren't chilling to upbeat synths you're on a streamlined, fast-paced bender of action/RPG goodness. Cutting down hordes of mobs is the order of the day, unhindered by one of  the smoothest control schemes I've ever tangled with, cleanly autodetecting keyboard, mouse, and gamepad inputs on the fly. Numerous waypoints let you scale expeditions to your liking without getting lost. Numerous game sounds alert you to the various activities on screen, from loot pickups to mousing over UI elements. Even typing in the chatbox has SFX to let you know that, yes, you are interacting with the game and not just quietly throwing words into the void. If there is one thing this game does right, it's the fact it doesn't get in the way of you playing it.

And its flaws are numerous, from oversights in programming and design to the toxic philosophy of F2P gaming. Lacking a heavy investment in debugging and QA, IMC has been patching reported errors (including a glaring LUA exploit that literally destroyed guilds) since day 1 of early access, and continues to be plagued with unpredictable downtimes, emergency maintenance, unreliable latency and bumpy framerates. (I run a  GTX 660 and can maintain 30+ fps in a crowded city, yet users with more powerful machines have had severe trouble, and I don't mean the Wahhh give me 120 fps 4K gaming" kind.)

TOS is ambitious with a mix-and-match style of class and skill progression

reviewText:
Just going to summarize with points. In short, even after 400+ hours, I don't recommend this game. Also be wary, lots of these positive reviews are from brand new players who are too caught up in the huge amount of early game content and haven't yet hit the wall of restrictions and inconveniences that only exist in this version of the game. After a while, the nostalgia just can't mask the flaws...

+ Very nostalgic and brings me back to the days where I played a lot of RO and MapleStory
+ Big variety of classes so you can be very creative with your build if you want to be
+ Early-Mid Game goes by super fast so just by playing a few hours a day, you can experience a lot of the game
+ Lots of different control schemes, controller is fun to play with imo
+ Great artwork and soundtrack
+ Cool gameplay mechanics. Think interactive quests and action-mmo combat.

And that's all the positive things about this game, to me. Here's everything that is wrong with the game in my opinion:
- Huge class imbalance. While you can any build you want, only a handful are viable after a certain level and even then, most are undesired for end-game content. Lots of classes are just plain underpowered and we haven't gotten any class balance changes for 2 months. (korean version has gotten them)
- Terrible game optimization. The way this game was programmed makes it utilize your CPU for most of the graphical processing instead of your GPU, and on top of that, it's written to only use a single core of your CPU. I have 300+ FPS on League of Legends on maxed settings and struggle to maintain 120 FPS on this game. Most of the time I'm averaging 70 FPS in fields, 30 FPS in dungeons, and like 15 FPS in populated towns. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing stupid.
- Terrible servers and netcode. I don't know why they bought servers that start to lag unbearbly with just 2,000 players online, but they did. Everyone's suffering for it. Also the netcode of this game was written with the Korean infrastructure in mind. Some classes can't even be played to their potential because your ping will never be low enough or consistent enough to combo/spam effectively.
- Bugs. Yeah, every new game has bugs. But lots of these bugs have been around since the beta of 2015 and they haven't been fixed. Lots of them are gamebreaking. Yet another issue that is dragging IMC's name in the mud.
- Unforgiving for new players. Yeah, if you ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up your build then you will start over. So all new players need to a good amount of research on what they want to play before making their characters. There are also no free skill resets or even a buyable stat reset. So if you done goofed, ya donezo.
- Lack of late-game content. Yup..PVP Battle League isn't live yet, GvG, Guildwars and etc. are a nightmare due to the poor optimization of this game. Right now the only thing to do once you hit cap is farm World Bosses for drops, and attempt the Earth Tower" dungeon that nobody's beaten yet. Not that big of an issue since IMC is adding more content

Totally unacceptable, specially when they had more than two or three beta tests over the last year. Specially when they sold ALOT of founder's pack. The game officially launched" as Free2Play a week ago with no stability at all and a totally unprepared team to manage it.

I strongly recommend people who haven't played the game so far to stay away from it UNTIL IMC Games get their sh#it together as your game experience will probably be undermined due to all the problems around."

reviewText:
First off I enjoyed the game quite a bit.  Great music, great art, fun class system. There is a lot of grinding to the game and to all the people complaining about camped zones, I have a few tips.  If you are in a heavy populated channel,  change channels and start inviting or requesting invites for a party.  When a party member kills, obtains,  activates a quest item it gives credit to all nearby party members.  I have not had any issue finding the mobs or quest items needed.

The biggest problem and turn off currently is the LAG.  If you have to pickup more than 1 quest you have to change channels and wait for load screens or you end up sitting at the quest person for minutes waiting for server to respond with the NPC dialog box.  This goes the same with most quests that require you to activate items.  The first action on a channel seems lag free and then it goes downhill fast, making constant channel switching the most efficient way to play.   This is garbage and servers need to be updated asap.   Also because some channels are constantly being restarted by the server causing a disconnect when you join a mew one, you can end up back into a waiting queue if you do channel hop so be careful.

TL:DR -  In the current state of things I would not recommend this game due to the shoddy servers.  Please save yourself the trouble and do not start playing on F2p release because you will end up frustrated and disgusted quickly by the server states.  Wait maybe a month or 2 after release and then give it a go.  It is a beautiful game but the lag issues were present in both CB's and its doubtful to be resolved upon f2p release.

reviewText:
- Servers are garbage, one moment you have 20ms ping the next 400ms.

- Market restrictions are a joke, if you start playing you have to wait 3 days to use the market, and even then you only get to place a single item to sell (with a 24h delay before you can get the money)

- The game is poorly optimezed, cities are the biggest fps hits because the game can't handle so many people on screen.  Even if you manually edit files and get the game to become stable at 60fps, cities will still be a pain to walk around.

- Control schemes are somewhat clunky, specially for mouse+keyboard players (sometimes the interaction doesn't show up for mouse)

- Despite all that, the combat is fun, the classes are interesting, the  art style is fantastic, and I'm having fun.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I wouldn't recommend this game to people, right now. This game has potential, but there's a whole bunch of silly things (In my opinion) that need to have been dealt with before the games release.

-The lag, I can understand because it's new and it'll have a bunch of F2P players coming in; but it means I haven't been able to try out classes that need decent ping, and buffing is a nightmare.

-I dont understand how the optimisation in this game is so bad. You can have everything on the lowest settings and still just about scrape by 30fps.

-Awful quality of life in game. They focussed more on bots than real people who would play the game. Bots won't care what you do, they'll still do bot things because they don't have opinion, every MMORPG has them and it's just something that needs to be accepted.

-They put up pay walls behind tokens, but didn't have an option to purchase them on release, and you still cant buy them almost two weeks later.

-Now here's my biggest issue: The spawn rate. Grind MMORPGs are probably my favourite. Yeah, the whole instant reward from questing with exp cards and all that is fun, but I do enjoy getting with a group of people and just grinding my way though levels, because it is nice when you go through that work and achieve a high level. Unfortunately, the system has low spawn rate with pretty mediocre experience gain. Along with the system that gives you less experience/damage the larger your level gap from the mob is.

All in all, I think once they get the game going it could be very good, just these issues make it a pain.

reviewText:
I have spent a lot of time in this game to give a proper review about it.

The idea behind the game is good, but the execution is horrible. The game is full of game-breaking bugs that didn't get fixed since the CBT, the game is a grind-fest with horrible monsters AI, bosses are badly designed(too easy = no challenge), you won't get challenged by their mechanics, only by the fact that all the monsters 200+ have HUGE HP and OVERPOWERED homing skills that you can't dodge. This isn't fun at all.

The game proposes a ton of classes for you to waste a lot of time trying to create the BEST class you feel comfortable with, when in fact the game isn't balanced at all, making only a few viable builds. For example, swordsman tree is so bad, that even if you do a full DPS swordsman build, you won't be able to outdps a FULL tank/con mage.

Quests are boring, just a way for you to get max level easier, but all those problems I stated aren't the worse of them. The game has been around for a while and all we get are patches done by their company's trainee, cause they only fix bugs that don't interfere with the game. They company don't listen to the players' feedback. I have reported a few bugs I have found and I all got was an automated response from their ticket service.

Oh, and the game's optimization... Oh god, this game is SO BADLY OPTIMIZED that you will get 0~10 FPS(in bosses/gvg's etc) even with the BEST RIG avaiable. The servers are always FULL and LAGGY, I live close to the server and my ping is around 200 when I should in fact have a ping of 10~40.

The good points of this game are: awesome soundtrack, beautiful design, but these are easily overshadowed by the bad management of IMC and the game's poor gameplay.

reviewText:
I think people are getting caught up by this game's looks, instead of focusing on the game itself. It's got a lot of issues.

- The leveling system is broken. Monsters have massive HP bars and give very little experience when killed, which turns leveling up into a massive chore.  The game keeps giving the player these XP scrolls for some reason, instead of bumping up the XP you get from killing monsters, which is the whole point of a game like this.

- No PvP mode. Seriously? PvP was a huge part of the late game in Ragnarok Online and it's baffling to me how it's nowhere to be seen in ToS.

- Lack of Gear Customization. The card system in Ragnarok Online was awesome and it had a lot of depth. In ToS, you only have these boring gems that have no depth to them whatsoever.

- The developers LOVE to toot their own horns, saying how deep the class system in this game, and how many classes there are, when in reality, the class system in ToS is not even half as deep as the class system in Ragnarok Online. Quality, not quantity is what I always say.

- The Boss Fights are BORING and repetitive. Do you guys remember how awesome it was to fight an MVP in Ragnarok Online? How badass they looked and how they could one-shot your character if you weren't careful? ToS's bosses have more in common with Diablo 3's than Ragnarok's bosses.

- Lack of an Attack Speed counter/stat. This is more of a personal opinion, but it really bums me out how you can't really measure or change your attack speed in the game.

- The controls are terrible. When your Korean MMO controls best on an Xbox 360 pad, you know you got problems. The Mouse controls are buggy as all hell and the Keyboard controls are just not fun to mess around with. I just don't get why they didn't stick with Ragnarok Online's control scheme? You shouldn't have to play a PC MMO with an Xbox 360 pad.

There's a reason why people still play Ragnarok Online 11 years after it came out. That game has depth, it knows how to keep the player engaged, it has an awesome PvP mode, group events, Guilds actually mean something and above all, it's fun to play. Tree of Savior looks better and that's pretty much it. I'm absolutely devastaded by how this game turned out, but I'm not gonna be deceived by its familiar code of paint like a lot of people did. I'd recommend you to give it at shot when it becomes free in April, but it's definitely not worth your money at this point.

reviewText:
I really want to recommend this game (This is supposed to be the actual 'successor' to Ragnarok Online, which I played back in early 2000), but in it's current state, I really can't recommend it.

1.  Lag.  The lag is awful and I don't think it'll get any better once the game gets out of the 'month early access'.  It'll only get worse.  Not to mention when I played earlier, channels were crashing, leaving a lot of players to go to 3 channels.  I ended up logging out because getting any quests done was next to impossible.

2.  F2P players are at a disadvantage.  You can't do trades unless you have the 'subscription' aka token active.  Like really????  Trading is a basic feature in nearly every mmo!  Account wide storage is also behind this wall, which can be a real pain if you're playing more than 2 classes.  You get extra speed too, which is useful, but this could be a problem in PvP down the line.

3.  Shoutting gold spam.  Every night I come on, I have to block the wall of gold spam.  It wouldn't be bad if the chat wouldn't lag the game.  ~_~  At this point, just turn shouts off.

4.  Quests are boring.  Very generic quests, but how many ways can you make kill -insert mob here- interesting?  Also, make sure you cover every base on a map, quest NPCs are not marked, so you have to watch for a npc anc click on them to see if it's a quest.  Can miss out on exp because you're not combing every corner of the map.

5.  Research is a must.  Before you play, I would highly suggest you goggle the game and see what builds are recommended.  Granted, there's a skill/stat reset, but you might save yourself money/time by doing some research yourself.

6.  Some bugs.  I came across 2 quests I could not complete.  Both of them, I could not interact with the object I needed to interact with.

7.  Combat is rather boring.  As a cleric, I lay down heal, lure monsters in to attack them, and if the monsters are 'floaty', I have to bash it to death with my mace.  Rinse and repeat.  I'm hoping there's more involved at later levels, but so far, I'm not impressed.

The good about this game?  It's a very pretty looking game and the music is there.  But as they say, graphics cannot save mediorc gameplay.

Could this be a good game?  Yeah, with some polish, it could very well be a good mmo.  But in it's current state?  I don't see myself playing it long term.  I might use as much as I can on the token I used and just move on to something else if nothing comes.

reviewText:
would I recommend this game to others? Probably. Would I recommend this game to RO Players? No.

First let's just start off from my background and why I wanted to play the game, and I'll be very brief in this.

TL;DR  We played alot of RO back in the days and loved it

Years ago, I and my friends fell in love with an MMORPG called Ragnarok Online, it was the best mmo we've played for a long time, to the point where we would even use our monthly allowance to pay for time in the game instead of things like food and stationery. The game had everything we loved, great music, vast world, danger even in safe areas, and the freedom to decide on what we want to do, how to do it, and how to grow our characters, it was basically a great adventure for all of us.

Years past by, and we heard of Ragnarok Online 2: Gate of the world, the music was alright but the game wasn't that good, and then there was the infamous Ragnarok Online 2: Legend of the second, I don't want to go into the details on this but let's just say that we decided that we're better off playing E.T. the video game (we didn't), than RO2.

And then Tree of Savior was announced, and boy were we excited, we made a promise to return together and we waited, and now that it officially opened, we were disappointed...

Tree of Savior isn't a bad game as a whole, it has good points like;
- The freedom to build your character however you like
- Nice music (though personally not as great as RO1's)
- Great artwork and design
- Good flow of combat
- Easier UI
- The Goddesses are packed with good Plot" ( Õ°¬∞ Õú ñ Õ°¬∞)b

However it is packed with problems that does put a damper on the game such as;
- Bugs
- The requirement for premium to do things like trading

reviewText:
Whew where do I begin... To start off I had played Ragnarok Online for a couple of years an had plaed other MMOs as well. So let's start off with the Pros:

1. Good Graphics - artistic and unique
2. Satisfying gameplay - gameplay is really satisfying since most skills will often have a substantial effect on opponents and allies. There are still some skills that need tweaking and bug fixing; however, I woudl say that the game's gameplay is still really solid.

Cons:

1. Grind- I have reached level 190. I can tell you that I have reached several grind walls already but the grind in this game is absurd. What happens if you're 10 levels above or below a monster? 10 levels above a monster = less exp (starting from being 5 levels below or above a monster); however,  being 10 levels below will make the monsters hit you harder in addition to having much less exp gain. It's gotten to the point that you really have to read on guides on how to use the exp cards efficiently due to the nature of the grind of this game and how unforgiving it is in terms of gaining experience due to leveling restrictions.

To top it all off, skill resets are only allowed through the use of premium currency, which is extreemely poor taste due to how much grind is involved and how the skill descriptions are really poor.

2. Trade restrictions - My god... I have never seen a game so heavily restrict on it's trading before. You can list only 1 item on the market (non premium user) and you can only trade with other players without the use of the in game currency, which prompts you to barter. Access to the market is only in towns as well. This makes market use cumbersome and often not worth using for the most part, at least from my experience.

3. Pay to win- sever items from the cash shop give combat advantages. Token = movespeed. Enchant scroll = provides you headgear with stat increases. Mind you that these increases are quite substantial, regardless of what people tell you otherwise.

4. Techinical issues- bots, server instabilities, etc. Can be fixed

5. Class Balance and equipment balance - can still be fixed; however, I really will say that the items and class balance are really out of whack right now. As an example for equipment, I am loaded with recipes but I have no materials to craft them even though I keep killing monsters, which often have spawn rates or mob densities that want us wanting more in normal maps. Not that the materials have any value on the market anyway nor can I actually sell them anyway due tot he trade restrictions hahaha.....

Overall, the game is still really rough around the edges and has still to go through a lot to improve. Currently, seeing how this is going to lift it's limited access soon to F2P players, I want to warn prospective players that this is brings in a lot of the archaic and not so good aspect of past MMOs and fails to bring the sandbox feeling of RO in the game with all the restrictions involved.

TL;DR - remove restrictions, improve archaic and obsolete MMO design (e.g. old world boss design, market access, bad spawn rates, etc.), make the grind more bearable, and balance issues in terms of skills and equipment aquisition.

reviewText:
A good bit of Ragnarok Online nostalgia when starting to play the game, but as many other reviewers have said there are so many cons.

Terrible lag (atleast for EU) makes you feel incredibly disconnected (emotionally, and technically) from the game.

Art style of the game is great and the boss style monsters are fun. The music is also quite good if you enjoyed the RO soundtrack.

A large amount of grinding is also required (google Tree of Savior exp graph)

Class diversity is great, but if you don't preplan using a calculator and make wrong decisions along the way you're going to need to start all over again!

Wait till it's free to play if you want to try the game out, watch some gameplay videos and check out other peoples reviews as well to get a more informed decision.

reviewText:
There are a lot of problems with this game. Some are in the publisher's control, some aren't. I'm going to skip the ones that are not in the publisher's control.

1) Progression/Gameplay
A lot of good mmo's in my opinion is like going to a theme park. Can go on whatever rides you want, a guide is going to give you a general direction, but at the end of the day you will have progressed through the theme park doing what you want. This game is like going down a corridor. You HAVE to go through every zone that the game tells you to, in the order they want you to. Now that isn't necessarily a problem, until you realize that even when you follow all the game's instructions, it is almost impossible get to the appropriate zones at the appropriate level. Why? because there are secret quests chains, that are more or less manditory if you don't want to grind, and if you miss these quest chains you won't have enough experience to level up to get to the next level without being underleveled. Now that also isn't a problem until you find out that the spawn rates in this game is extremely low which means that you have to fight other people for mobs to kill. The problem is that this isn't like any other MMO where you tag it and its yours. The person that gets the killing blow in gets the credit (this is also a problem for questing, since everyone is fighting everyone else to get the last hit in). So what you have is, a bunch of people who have finished the quests in the area that are higher level than the people who just began the area, camping mobs that those lower players need for questing because they themselves are too underleveled to progress to the next area.

For example, I've finished every quest I can find and I'm in a level 50 zone, but my character is level 42. This means that I need to go back to a level 40 zone as a level 42 competing against people who are probably level 35 who are trying to finish their quests. They can't finish it because I'm out last hitting them, so they go back to a level 35 zone to try to catch up to 40, etc etc.

2) Lag/Server Issues
This is early access so the problem might be too many people being in the same area at the same time, but there is a huge issue with lag and response from the servers. Sometimes I try to interact with a NPC and  they don't respond until a couple seconds-minutes later. This might be alleviated if they got more servers or if the number of players drop in the areas. This might be the reason as to why the spawn rates are so low as to relieve some pressure off the servers. This is only going to get worse after F2P comes out.

Overall, there are problems in this game mechanically that are totally fixable by the publishers, but whether they will is another story.

reviewText:
If you are a solo player and want a head start on everyone else, do try it.

If you have friends who join you, definitely not recommended.

As a solo player the bugs will be pretty minimal imo. However once you are in a group of 2+ get ready to start throwing up your arms and face palming. I play with friends and all these issues have been a headache. Sure I can play alone but even then I can't play because the server tends to go down for maintenance because that's just my schedule.

Issues:
Bugged cinematics
Bugged warping
Bugged quest completions
Bugged drops
Bugged server
Bugged devs

No trading
No controlled loots (pray to RNG gods)

To me these are core aspects of a game. In a 2+ party the chances of these bugs occuring to someone is practically 99%. The game has such a great idea/system in place. Yet they completely failed their launch and are constantly handing out apologizes through the mail in terms of compensation. I purchased the EA3 pack so I'm not as butt hurt but seriously... Indie games have better releases and this is a AAA.

reviewText:
In its current state, I can't recommend the game to anyone. If you're going to play this game, be aware that you will probably run into a lot of issues. While the base foundation is there, the game is simply not ready for public access. Tree of Savior has one of the most over the top trade restriction that are built to combat gold sellers but wound up punishing its playerbase instead. Due to this games' low spawn rate and mob reward system, you're going to run into a fair amount of killstealing where you won't get quest progress or credit if you don't last hit a mob. Shout chat is still filled with gold seller shouts, and bots are running around freely in unpopulated and populated areas (granted, what free to play mmo doesn't have bots doing just that). There have been exploits, dungeon entry issues, server and channel entry issues, glitches and a lack of optimization that makes you question if IMC just wanted to push this out to make as much money as they can before it dies out.

I've also written a more detailed review and overview which you can visit by heading to the website below:
http://freetoplayreview.com/tree-of-savior-review
voteText: 57 of 107 people (53%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Played during the beta, and the game seemed promising, just needed some fixes and polish.
Release comes along, and old issues are still present.  Chat server still lags the entire game.  Overall game lag makes the game nearly unplayable.  All sorts of limitations even with a premium membership active reduce the fun for players in an attempt to stop bots and real money transaction sellers, but they are present and spamming away in chat, leaving real players with all the frustration of bots and un-fun limitations.

Gameplay is simple, yet fun.  Soundtrack is great.  the class system is wildly varied and would be a blast to play around with... you know, if the game was actually functioning the way a customer should expect a game to work.

The server lag may eventually lessen as players leave, but poor developer decisions may continue beyond that to keep this game from being fun even then.  I'll keep an ear out and see if the game improves eventually, and may change this review if it does.  For now though, this game is not worth playing in the slightest.

reviewText:
Tree of Savior is a fairly decent MMO, but somehow doesn't feel much different to me than Korean MMOs from 10 years ago, like Lineage 2. I don't hate it, but I have, already in fact, recommended to a friend to hold off on getting it. I think one day it COULD be really good, but I don't believe there are any defininig qualities of this game that would get me to recommend leaving a different MMO for this one.

The Bad:

-The biggest weakness to me has to be the story. It is translated fairly well, but even still it's very flat and bland, and unexciting. I'm almost level 50, and I honestly couldn't tell you anything about it....I know you are The Revelator" or whatever

reviewText: Another game with great art, music and class mechanics ruined by terrible management. The largest problem of the game is trading restrictions: free players can not trade at all and premium players are limited to 30 trades per month, furthermore once an item that isn't equipment is traded, it becomes untradable, which kills the game for merchants. The auction system isn't any better ‚àí free players are limited to one auction slot, while premium players have 5, which isn't nearly enough to sustain a healthy economy. Furthermore, there is a 48 hour delay before silver can be withdrawn from the auction house, which makes a lot of players not want to bother with it altogether.\nThe only ones who don't deem to suffer from all of these restrictions are bots and gold sellers, for whom it is a dream come true, considering all the extra clients they're getting because players aren't able to earn silver fairly. IMC has promised to soften the restrictins, yet have done nothing of the sort for two updates. And now to make things worse Steam regional pricing has been removed without warning, making the already expensive premium currency unaffordable for the majority of players. This just continues to show that IMC don't care about their players and are only trying to grab some fast cash.

This game has so many restrictions between trade restrictions, time duration of 48 hours to claim your money from the market, can't trade silver and blah blah it's been said in all kinds of other reviews, no sense repeating it.

Dungeon entry limits yay! I play MMOs cuz I love socializing and meeting new people. I can do that twice per day, per character then it's back to solo grinding quests in the field :P

I really wanted to love this game and I tried... 76 hours and all of those hours were playing the game, not idle or AFK. It was fun, really. But the restrictions everywhere just wore me down and tired me out. I couldn't do it anymore.

I feel like the people who will really enjoy this game (After they fix the lag... don't even get me started there LOL), are people whose playstyles match with the way the dev restrictions sorta... I dunno how to put it? The devs seem to want you to play their game exactly how they think you should play it? That's kinda how I felt while playing it. I couldn't do this, I couldn't do that, I had to wait for this.

In the end, it just didn't work out for me. Maybe it will work out for you? I'm not going to recommend it because I do feel an MMORPG should have a lot more player freedom to play than this game offers and Bots and RMT" should never

reviewText:
Product received for free

So many mix feelings about this game, a game that when you play feels so good but after some gameplay you start to find annoying after annoying little things.

Economy: if you want to sell an item, you can only announce a single one and it'll have a 30% tax ( if you have the premium 10 items and 10% tax), but you can't sell for any price that you want, as they have a min and max limits for every items. Trying to stop the gold selling the developers turn off the option of golf trade player-player ( meanwhile the gold sellers are using high price items to do the same thing or just buying a item for a high value in the market). So the gold sellers are still using bots, spamming the chats and selling silver while normal players are restrict. btw if you don't have premium account you can't even acess the public stash, so you'll have trouble to transfer that great staff to your wizard.

Monsters: there are so little of them, sometimes there are only 5-10 in the whole map. A single party can easily clean most of the maps and them you have to sit and wait for the long respawns. Some monsters can be erased from all the channels by a single player crossing the channels for rare monsters.

Support: my ticket already have a week, so I really pray to never have any serious problem.

The game is good, you can have fun. But you will have trouble with the market/trades and you won't have a good time while trying to farm for mons. It's a grind game that you can't grind because of the lack of monsters. They are also really trying to throw the players in certain servers. We use to have some public servers, now they are trying to separate so if you are from NA you will play NA servers, if you are from EU you'll play EU servers and so on.
A shame because this game could be so much more.

reviewText:
While we call this game true successor to RO, the graphic style and everything else is but the game play is not.
This game is more action oriented with a lot of RPG base element. ( with MMO lagging capability).
You can probably grind to LV up but it will be tedious and boring. The fastest way to LV up in this game is to quest.

Let's get to the detail.
- Level design is BEAUTIFUL BUT BAD ,especially in the begining where it require players to run around the map to the same place over and over and over again. It get better 90 LV later and might troll us to do it again every few quests.
My suggestion is - choose to start from Orsha than Klaipeda - better level design better rewards, less running in circle.

- Class Advancement looks very interesting that we have 50-80 classes to play but it is actually hard, confusing and there is no going back once player choose one( as of this patch). Once you mess up the only correction is to reset and play again.
... it feel good once you get it right finally...

- Skill cooldown is an ABOMINATION !! TOS will not let you spam skills like in RO instead even less powerful skill will require players to wait for 30 seconds to do 200% damage burst ... did I mention you only have 1-2 attack skills per class advancement?

- Status distribution is BORING !! The game is designed to have max LV around 500. Each status point we distribute early game is very insignificant. it feel really weak to have 50-100 status points in damage stats such as STR or INT a few PVP builds  tends to go fully HP oriented since skill damage doesn't scale much with the stats.

- Server lag will be fixed. Once it is this will be one of the game most people can enjoy.

- MUSIC IS GORGEOUS !!!

- GRAPHIC IS BEAUTIFUL !!! AND UNIQUE !!!

- While the game itself is not really optimised ... I play it at 60 FPS the it drop to 15-25 every now and then. Everytime I walk pass people and open a god damn map... or buff people ... or do AOE kills... I kinda don't mind it much. I heard a few people does.

- IMC garunteed there will be 200 bosses  to fight over ... they are all camped by high LV people and monopolised the market.

- You cannot trade money - I think they try to stop Chinese gold scammer but they still use Marketplace to do it. In the end this affect the in-game economy a lot.

- Trading only allow for VIP people, still no money trading... even VIP have limited number of times they can trade.
So I don't trade... much.

- TREE OF BUGs !!! bugs are every where. Seems like this tree attract more bugs than Bugframe or Bugscroll online.

- Game designer decide to help solo player ... with x6 experience with dungeon finder but give no bonus to normal party ... talk about double standards.

- Why am I still recommending this.... I'm drunk I guess. forget it play the game. see for yourself.

reviewText:
Greetings folks,
this will mostly be an appolagy letter towards my guild members.
though this will most likely provide some points for other players as well.

1st of all, i'm sorry guys for quiting the game.
after 300+ hours of trying to get templar it kind of started to tax on me.
specially the last levels of trying to get towards templar was tedious and yes i know i wasnt the quickest to reach it
i'm sure there are quicker ways to get rank 7 yet that wasnt me.
but after finally reaching templar things were looking up for a while.
i was happy when i finally obtained the guild, gained some fun members. and had a good time socializing with others.

alas this was just a short bliss as about a week after i started to learn how empty of a shell the guild system actually is.
it misses most if not all of it's features. and even then it lacked allot of stuff.
-no functional guild storage system.
-no functional guild events.
-no officer system
-no taming system
-barely functional farming system
-no neutrality system
-no indication of guild member levels so grouping up was hard to do
-no guild tower tp (how are members supose to go to a guild tower if they cant reach it
-expencive guild tower placement (100k) so if you misplace it, it would cost 100k more.
a bad upgrade system. (3 upgrades with bad options, taming not ingame, farming only 1 out of 6 possible seeds were available and +1 member cap per guild level)

i was quite demoralized after i realized how much the guild system was lacking, i ended up making a new character in the hopes of having more fun. but in the end i never really got the feeling of fun" my only goal in the game was getting the guild. now don't get me wrong i would most likely have played allot more if the guild had a good system but that didnt seem to be the case.

but it wasn't just the guild system that was bad.
the dungeons in this game were tedious
date: no real inovation in them. playing as a tank it felt like i was just taking the hits hoping i would not die. the mobs just didnt die quick enough. hell tbh the mobs were stronger than the bosses in most dungeons. and tbh that was the sad part about most of the dungeons. i never felt like any of the dungeons were fun.\ncomparing it to aura kingdom(AK) or ff14 dungeons all mobs
recommended:
bosses and area's were bad.
in AK and FF14 it felt like you were tanking. in this game? well lets just say it didnt feel like any of that.

when i started that new character i quickly came to the realisation that the only way to play the game anymore since launch was to ks ks and ks. hoping to get the exp while people run amok. it wasnt fun to play. even knowing were to go didnt speed things up.

finally at launch i expected them to finally add propper things to the TP shop
hoursPlayed:
well lo and behold. they added nothing.
in the i think 2 months i was playing this game they added 1 set of costumes that were all PINK. yes i'd love to see my warrior in pink. i really do. (sarcasm)
the fact that after choosing a class i wasnt able to change it ever forces you to go with other characters for other builds.

the chat system was so tedious that half the time whisper chat didnt work. matter a fact everything in this game was just a shell of what it could have been.

i must say after a total of 420+ hours of playing this game. i never really felt great playing it.
i hoped for the game to get more fun when i finally had a guild to play it with. but even that was just an illusion of my imagination.

anyway
voteText:
with this last review of the game i leave the game behind me.

thank you for reading and maybe in the future this game might be worth looking at again.

for now

reviewText: While the game publisher made some questionable decisions, the game itself have no soul. that's why it's bad. Yeah it's pretty, with gorgeous music and glorious locations - but it's linear and empty. You would never return to those locations, you will stop looking at scenery before you even reach 100, and you won't get any joy from listening this music after another tedious set of repetitive quests with obligatory bosses. That's not a RO successor I waited for 3 years.

reviewText:
Like every rewiev, this is subjective. I won't list all the flaws and perks because you can find those mentioned everywhere, but I will instead list what I personally consider to be the main flaws of the game, the features that are making me turn away from this otherwise decent game.
My apologies for the lenght, but I can't express myself in a more concise way.

A multiplayer game that encourages you to be antisocial.
Dungeons provide more experience if you join the queue solo, and belive me when I say you NEED experience badly, you won't pass on the opportunity, therefore you will feel discouraged to group up with your friends to do them.
No chance to create chat channels in game and it takes an almost-max level character to create a guild (if you want the guild chat), if you want some sort of interaction you ought to join one of the many discord channels the community is providing.
The limited number of transactions discourages you from trading items with your friends, potions to heal them, or equipment so they can try yours, or even just random loot to complete the daily quests (go out and collect xxy item).
Damage delaers are encouraged to killsteal as much as possible, not just because they are selfish, but in many cases the very slow respawn rate on enemies, encourages players to play as every man for himself". Supports get the short end of the stick.



A grinding game without places where to grind.
After a certain point

reviewText:
My only complaint is that features like 1:1 trading are locked behind a pay wall and frame rates drop to about 30fps around the Orsha statue, but I think that's due to lag and not really the game being poorly optimized as it runs over 100fps in lowly populated areas.

I never played Ragnarok Online but have over 6k hours in WoW and some time in FF14, so I love games like this.  I'm okay with the features the token gives you aside from the speed boost (as I'm sure PvP zones will be introduced and this will eventually become a P2W feature) since PvP seems based around classes that can escape/teleport/flee to safety, heal up, and come back to the fight.  If you're going to give a speed boost, just make it enabled for PvE zones only so that it's just a way to level a character faster, not a feature that becomes necessary to win in PvP.

Otherwise, I can't recommend this game enough.  The gameplay is super fun and addicting and if it weren't for my work and school schedule right now, I'd probably have sunk the entire last 2 days into it.  I absolutely love the punishing class system but I agree that skill resets should be locked behind in-game currency (silver) and not behind premium currency, just make the respec extremely expensive so that people think twice about it.  Otherwise, the possibilites seem endless when it comes to customizing your character and plenty of the skills seem viable for PvE and PvP.  It forced me to do some research before playing the game so I had an idea of where I was going to put my skill points and attribute points.

Highly recommended.

EDIT: Charge full price for the game, don't make it F2P.  The model you're following is not working right now.  This game feels too empty and single player to be called an MMO.  Where are the /clap /cheer /whatever kind of emotes that are typical of WoW, FF14, or any other MMO?  Why is the market place such a mess?  Why doesn't Round Robin work?  I hear there are guilds in this game; I've yet to see one.

Please enable trading for free; that's the most ludicrous thing I've ever heard of.  An MMO where you can't trade items.  What?

I would be happy to pay $15/month like WoW or FF14 if the content was good enough to merit it.  Think of it from a monetary standpoint; FF14, with a free 30 days, for $20, has about 400-500 hours of content in the base game.  Just think about that for a second...  Vanilla WoW, when it first came out, had enough content to keep people busy for months for the base $60 game.  This game has enough content for people that are obsessed with grinding and love alts, but I feel that people who want a regular MMO experience will be wholly turned off by the direction and limitations of this game.

reviewText:
This game has been released for a couple of weeks, during which time it's gone from bad to worse.

It started off with a massive amount of bots. They devised a system of reporting, which reduced the number of bots to maybe... half? But half of a lot is still a lot.

Then the software glitches started happening. People simply could not play the game anymore. Multiple rounds of downtime to fix it, and it hasn't been resolved for a significant number of players.

Adding to the  mismanagement in general was the lag that came about from allowing server transfers. More people transferred to specific servers than could be safely managed and now we've all got insane amounts of lag. Dungeons take an hour to pop, if you're lucky, despite the fact that you're matched with a party and good to go within a minute of queuing. The queue just... resets itself and you're just left waiting when you could be doing much better things with your limited time in-game.

It has been an absolutely attrocious experience. I'm an avid gamer for over 20 years running and this is easily the most horribly, poorly thought out release I've ever had the misfortune of participating in. People are saying that we should give this game time, but considering how much money has poured in from DLCs, they should have adequate support to sort out basic problems like JUST PLAYING THE GAME as was promised.

People are spamming the forums multiple times daily screaming at the GMs what the most fundamental problems are, and for the most part they've gone ignored.

reviewText:
This game... it's like trying to run a Ferrari on Potato fuel.

First of all, the game posses a wide variety of soundtrack and BGM, each unique and changes depending on what map or battles you were in. This shows that the Developer (or atleast the original Developers a.k.a Koreans) had a vast access to manpower and tools in order to generate all of these beautifully composed musics. They're an essential if you were to indulge yourself fully into each of the gameplay.

Now, the art part. Majestic, beautiful and gives a nostalgic vibe for veteran MMORPG players who missed the Ragnarok days. The sheer pixel of each everything, varying from backgrounds to mobs' heads, you won't find anything that does not fit anywhere, other than also allowing you to appreciate how detailed the surrounding really are.

But that's where all the kisses and praises ends.

As far as I have went into the gameplay itself, I could say of one thing. Their server runs on potato. There are major lags hopping on you everywhere, you can't hide from them. You'd get disconnected at times for no reason, failing to enter your specific server etc. etc. This drastically affect the whole gameplay itself since it interrupts your playing experience.

Now, this is one thing that I hate the most. Token users. Seriously? I mean, if it's extra exp buff, movement speeds and things as such, I'd probably find myself unfazed and let it slip past by. But to be a token user so that you can trade between players (OH and not to mention the 30 times limit and the fact that you can only trade between Token users?) Come on, what in the heck is MMORPG when you can't trade between players?

The commission for using the Market is also neck-choking. 30% of your sale price is a pretty big bite out of nowhere, just to end up turning into useless codes. Again, this may be decreased to half if you were a Token user, thus leading me to believe it's there just to be another 'fish-bob' for players to buy Tokens.

There are more flaws than I could handle to mention, but as the Developers are actively doing their best to fix the game to be a better day for everyone, I can't help but to give them another chance. Thumbs up for them, and hopefully, for the better future of the game. I'd hate to let go of this game, not when it reminds me so much of Ragnarok.

I will edit this review as time passes by, so do your best Developers, don't fail our hopes and hypes.

23/4/2016 EDIT:-

Seriously Developers? Raising the price of the Early Access Packages, other than also getting the 3rd one out of the shelves? After looking at the prices of these DLCs, they're like 3x times the previous price! Trying to cover it all up with a 50% sale? What a disgrace, I'm utterly disappointed. If this is an attempt to stop bot from spreading, then I rather say this is an attempt to get more money from Early Access Users.

OH AND LOOK AT THAT, PUSHING THE F2P RELEASE DATE? Lame, Developers. Lame. You may say that this is to provide more time for bug fixing and calibrating, but what I see here is yet another attempt to squeeze more money from future DLC buyers.

But guess what? With all these 'good' reviews exploding, your future seem bleak, my friends. It was such a great game, but sadly, it fell into the hands of stupid devils.

Hate
-  Raikuri

reviewText:
I came in to this game with high expectations as a Ragnarok fan and very disappointed after 200 hours of gameplay, the latter half of which I felt obblied to play not to abandon the friends caught in the hype I created myself.

The main reason I left this game is quite simple: it's almost unviable to play this game with your friends. The game upgrading is so centered in doing unrepeatable quests, added to the high level restrictions, that playing with the same people became a frustrating battle of perfectly syncronizing your game progress with them.

The last time I played I was level 121 while my friends played half a day more and were ~127 and this little level discrepancy was enough for me to feel bad to ask them to lose their time to go back to where I was. This had happened so many times before I finally realize that this game is simply not for me.

Other than that, I also hugely criticize the p2w methods that IMC Games adopt and tell you if you wish to play this game competitively be ready to pay loads of real cash.
