reviewText:
Product received for free

ToS is a F2P Korean MMORPG focused on killing all the things with big bangs and explosions of big numbers covering the whole screen.

The Good stuff:
Beautiful mix of 2D and 3D art, in many games this just looks weird but ToS nails it perfectly and looks gorgeous.
Awesome soundtrack, several hours worth of varied music that one can grind for hours to without it getting stale.
Easy controls that work well both with keyboard and mouse or a gamepad, and very satisfying combat with attacks and spells that have 'impact'.  Unleashing devastating aoe attacks on large groups of monsters doesn't get old.
Character building has a lot of depth. Character levels increase base power with stat increases and every 15th class level you choose new or higher tiered sub classes, and as a result ToS offers a rare depth of character customization.
Bad stuff:
P2W. (This is debated.  With an expensive monthly premium token you get access to a movement speed buff, +30% XP boost,  trading restrictions lifted, and head enchants with stat increases which are all clearly P2W in my book)
Some servers are drowning in lag or down for maintenance for long periods of time.
Bots and gold sellers are everywhere.
Compared to the beta builds, monsters spawn rates are SEVERELY reduced.  In many places much more time is spend sitting around or searching for mobs, than actually fighting things.  Also means it takes a truly masochistic soul to even attempt to complete many of the item collections.
Very limited character creation, all you get is male/female, one of four classes, and choose your hair style.
ToS shows incredible promise for being a long staying and successful F2P mmorpg once the launch issues with bugs and server stability gets ironed out.  IMC also desperately needs to adress the monster spawn rate situation.

So with all these negatives listed why is this game still a thumbs up from me?  Cause despite it all, ToS is still an immensely enjoyable game for me that I'm having a lot of fun wasting away my hours on!

reviewText:
Summary

TOS is a beautiful 2.5D game with amazing artistic designs. Customization creates depth in the game-play. However, players interaction could be further encouraged. Game play needs to be more balanced. More varieties need to be implemented. Given the momentum of the developers, the game has a lot of potentials to be greater.

Pros

This game is an eye candy. The maps and character designs are amazing. It truly stepped up its game in the artistic department comparing to Ragnarok, which was a beautiful game to begin with. The map has different layers of backgrounds creating such depth. You may be crossing a bridge high up in the mountain while finding other players fighting monsters deep in a small valley underneath. A 2.5 D game with such style puts even many 3D MMORPG in shame.

The game offers an enjoyable RPG experience. It allows so much customization. The number of classes and skills in each allows two late game characters of the same class to have completely different play styles. The drop rate is decent. Gears are easy to get. I never find myself short of resource to buy merchandises. Free users are at little disadvantage comparing to the paying ones.

The devs are still actively fixing the game's issues. The lagging issue which was causing huge uproar was fixed in a week. The trade system has been brought back. The developers listen to what their customers want and they make it happen. This game is being constantly improved. Hopefully the user experience would be even better in the future.

Cons

The game struggles to create a cohesive experience as a MMORPG. It does not encourage players to cooperate. For example, doing quests alone is far more rewarding than anything else due to the low difficulty of the game. This results in every player focusing on playing alone rather than being part of the greater world. Remember the merchants on the streets of the major cities in Ragnarok making the world so lively? The market place is a cheap replacement to that formal glory. Even though there are plenty players, it lacks a spirit of a living world.

The classes are not balanced. Despite allowing customization, certain build provides far better leveling experience comparing to another. It requires user to do their homework before actually playing the game. Some skills are traps by being completely under-powered. It is not that kind of game which rewards you for being devoted to a certain path. Hence stepping on to the wrong path means either starting over or buying $ item to reset the character.

Lastly, behind its pretty face, the game gets repetitive really fast. All minions on every level feels the same from lv1 to lv50. It is great to fight a boss every now and then, but it feels like the same boss with different skins/animations except a few. Quest comes in different formats, but all too trivial. They should be more distinctive and memorable. However, the hidden ones are really pleasant surprises. I remember finding a red gem which took me to a boss battle against a monster guarding it. Make these more common! Overall, the grinding experience feels a bit bland.

Conclusion

It has been fun, but I am stopping playing this game because the cons outweigh the pros. I will not enjoy the same experience for another 35 hours. The game is still worth a try for new comers.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Honestly I can't recommend this game, all the issues that arise make it unplayable and frustrating.

The game itself is pretty fun, you got a lot of variety in classes and the combat is enjoyable, not your generic mmorpg type of gameplay, but that's pretty much where the positives stop.

It tries a bit hard to be Ragnarok, from visual design to certain mechanics, but it's obviously not. If you're going into the game looking for that, you'll be disappointed. There's a ton of monsters to kill, there's a big boss monster awaiting around every corner, but after a while I just start wondering whether those bosses were any different or meaningful to kill, none of them drop any interesting loot and overall the game is lacking in variety of loot. You have only a few tiers of items and often they don't even look different and you won't get any new usable items for a long time. You also find a ton of materials, but you got nothing to do with them, the crafting system is very shallow and boring.

There are performance issues, the game isn't optimized very well, but it's not a dealbreaker. My computer isn't amazing, like 5 years old at this point and the only times I get bad performance issues is in towns with a lot of people, which doesn't matter that much since most of the gameplay takes place in other areas, so while I see a lot of people complaining about this, I think this is a minor issue that can be overlooked.

Lag, however, can't be overlooked. If you ever played Lunia or Spiral knights and experienced lag in those games, you'll know what I'm talking about. This game is an action game that requires you to dodge attacks or attack and retreat, but the game is server based, meaning that every movement and attack you make on your screen doesn't matter, since it first has to register on the server and if there's even the slightest lag, things won't go your way. Even regular attacks become a chore to execute, as your character gets stuck after each attack until the server decides that you had executed the attack. Now you might say that lag is related to your internet rather than the servers, but that's not true, if you don't live anywhere near the servers(not the same continent), you're gonna have a bad time. Personally I get 150ms ping and that's already unplayable, at higher levels you need to react faster, but when enemies attack faster than your signal gets sent to the server and back, the game becomes unfair and frustrating. If the server is having issues, lags rise even higher and you start teleporting back constantly while going somewhere, enemies hurt you long after you ran past them and all kinds of things like that.

The jumping mechanic seems like an interesting feature for this kind of game, but it is useless and not done right. Most areas don't utilize it, most maps don't even let you fall down from places to lower ground and just force you to go around or don't let you jump over some low obstacles like fences as if there's no such thing as jumping in the game. Jumping is meant to be used as an evasion maneuver and it's meant to be a split second action, but since the game is server based, if you're experiencing lag you can't use that at all to your advantage.

Bots and spammers are also a big issue in the game, there's constant spamming and advertising of gold selling sites, the people that spam don't get banned for hours and keep spamming it in shouting chat which scrolls their message across the top of the screen all the time, which can't be turned off. Even after blocking a lot of those people, they constantly make new users and spam more and more of their crap. You also see a bunch of bots around the battlefields, reporting them doesn't seem to help much. I get that this issue is difficult to deal with for the GMs, but it's still incredibly annoying, I forgot that these things even exist considering I haven't seen them for a couple of years.

Overall, I really dislike that this game is so server reliant, I get that it helps prevent cheating and all that, but it's also preventing me from playing the game properly, just like it used to be with Lunia and Spiral Knights for me.

reviewText:
Despite the lag spikes, the skill delays, skill freezes, framerate drops, various bugs... here we are, still playing. Despite the not-so-well-thought of 1:1 trades, restrictions that targets Silver Sellers and bot farmers but backfired, 2-day delay on earnings made on the Marketplace, crazy 10% minimum tax on said Marketplace as a VIP, Premium Token that seems lackluster for a 12 USD value... here we are, still playing. Despite what seems to be devs not listening to the community, bug fixes that seems to take an eternity for the devs to fix, hiccups on the DLC and now a long delayed TP bundle offerings, the few competent, community-loved staff members getting removed from work by IMC, and now with the hate generated by a certain ethnicity in the SEA servers and NA counter-part... here we are STILL PLAYING.

The amount of time I've spent in this game is a pretty nice chunk of time I could've spent on something else, something more productive I suppose. I, too, have a couple of ill-things to say, but here I am, still playing...

It is a game with a mixed review. Not everyone will love the grindy nature of this MMO. Ragnarok Online still seems much better than this actually. Does that mean this game is not worth your time? Well, if you did laid hands on Ragnarok Online and other Korean made MMOs, and you loved it, chances are you will feel at home in this game. RO stood the test of time, something ToS has a lot of as well. Would it become a gem with a very rigorous polishing? Maybe.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Tree of savior is a curious creature, it feels a bit like a breath of fresh air in a crowded and uninspired MMO-space, but at the same time it is also crucially recreating an almost ancient model from the Ragnarok Online era. There is a lot to love in this game, the warm, hand-drawn art direction and extremely wide class options are instantly appealing. One thing I particualrly enjoyed was the absurdly archaic inspirations they used for many of the game's more unsual jobs. The Divedirbys, for example carves various holy statues in battle, and is based on an actual real world profession. Many other jobs draw from disparate cultural sources including ancient korea, feudal japan, and wide swaths of middle aged cultures in the baltic regions.

However, the game is not without faults. It lacks a strong narrative backdrop, and even major questlines are riddled with poor translations and mark-up errors. Town hubs can become almost comically overpopulated, though players can usually fix this by changing instances. The underlying gameplay can also grow repetitive, and consists largely of grinding on the same chump monsters as you cut a path to large boss encounters. With a group of friends, this gameplay is a great backdrop for social engagement, but I can't imagine it would remain fun for long as a solo experience.

reviewText: I've been to RO1, RO2 and was hoping to get a better experience in this game. I bought the Founders Blah Blah, to be able to play this game, hoping to get much from what I paid. At first, it was fun, coz I am playing with my bro. I didn't mind all its faults thinking that the game will get better and better soon. I suffer from very low FPS, though I have a unit with high specs -higher than the recommended, I suffer from delays and lags in dugeons though I have an excellent connection. I've been into a lot of MMOs, and they all run smooth, except for TOS. I just can't understand why. I am not a techie person, and I don't know anything about optimization and the like, but through reading reviews, I came up with a realization that this game has not leveled with the fun and enjoyment I experienced playing in RO1. That is why, my plans to recommend this game to my friends would remain an elusive dream forever. I still play though, at least a couple of hours in a day, farming for arde dagger, and doing the 3/3 mercenary quest. But to explore the game more? I doubt if I'd still have the interest. I am just waiting for my token to expire, then, I don't know what will happen next. It killed my interest in playing with other MMOs, this game made me tired and unhappy...#peaceout

reviewText:
Product received for free

Let's see, 3rd of June, 2016. |A newbie's approach|

This game got many negative reviews from bugs that happened during beta and release and some other in-game features which I haven't met yet. Personally I did not play it neither on beta nor on release, today was my first day and it went like this:

Cons:
-Noticed a small 0.5 delay, which by the time (Must have been with pop. per server) it went away.
-Minor bugs on the game
-It seems it needs a bit of grinding
-I use Logitech F310 gamepad and the input of the buttons its kinda f'd up and I can't customize it
-Not newb-friendly for various reasons (If you plan on investing in this game you have to study about classes and stuff)
Pros:
-It's approachable by both Casual and Hardcore audiences, since as a casual you can easily reach level 50+ and feel acomplishment and hardcore, cause after 100+ ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• gets real.
-It has side-quests and Map % Exploration along with some 'journey recording achievements' which for me (Kinda the perfectionist-style) it's a really nice feature.

In conclusion: I guess if you really like that type of game, cause personally I fell in love with the art, design and the whole idea, you just get over the cons. It's a really fun time-killer.

reviewText:
My experience with Tree of Savior so far has been a rollercoaster of emotions ranging between love and frustration to the point of wanting to delete my character.

Positives:+ The gameplay is very enjoyable for what it is, a little unchallenging maybe, but fun.
+ The game has a wide range of customizability of character. Even so much that it is overwhelming at glance. You are presented with 4 base class options, each of which can further evolve into more specialized variants, tallying up to a total of 80 available classes.
+ Amazing artstyle, amazing OST.

Negatives:- In it's current state the game runs very badly at times. VERY badly.
- Many bugged quests, so far I've run into two MAIN STORY quests that prevented me from progressing because they were broken.
- Gold sellers are running rampant in-game to the point where you have to completely disable the global chat channel to not have your chatbox filled by messages from Zskdfjgklh and friends at all times.
- Trading is completely locked behind a paywall in a game advertised as free to play". F2p players have access to the market but are restricted to selling a single item at a time.
- You're only allowed to enter dungeons twice a day. Not twice per dungeon
date: but two dungeons per day overall.\n\nOther things:- Premium status gives benefits such as permanent increased movement speed
recommended: +20% experience gained from combat and increased maximum buff count.\n- The game doesn't do a good job of educating you about how building a character works. Leveling the wrong stat or picking the wrong class can "ruin" your character permanently very easily. Upon realization you either have to remake or redesign your character
hoursPlayed:
or play with a gimped character.


I will most likely continue the game but I would not recommend it as the experience is very frustrating most of the time. Regardless I feel like there is a gem hidden in this pile of dirt
voteText: and if IMC manages to fix all or at least most of the issues causing tension in the playerbase the game has potential to be great."

reviewText:
After paying for several DLC packs and playing for two months, all I can say is... Tree of Savior is meh. IMC is lucky to have people dubbing the game as RO's successor because if it weren't for that, this game wouldn't have built up so much hype. It's just like all the other modern" MMOs out there.

1. It's your typical theme park MMO; doing quests is pretty much necessary because they give a good amount of EXP (through EXP cards) and certain areas can't be accessed without doing some of the quests.

2. Don't expect to be able to freely play your character however you want
date:
because there's a specific path you must take in order to progress in the game.

3. There are so many classes and this would've actually been good if it weren't for the quests. Wanna try a new class? Prepare to go through the same exact quests you just finished on your first character.

4. Monster AI is so simple and stupid. I can provoke a whole screen's worth of mobs and kill every single one of them with just auto attack. No strategy involved at all. Bosses aren't very challenging either although they aren't as boring as non-boss monsters.

5. So many class possibilities yet so little gear choices. Perhaps the devs spent too much time designing the classes so they completely overlooked the importance of gear options?

6. Trade system is god damn awful. You know there's something wrong when you can't trade the game's main currency.

7. The game has three "modes" - Keyboard Mode
hoursPlayed: Controller Mode. Mouse mode is buggy as ****. The devs shouldn't have implemented it if they couldn't get it right.\n\nIn my opinion
voteText:
these are this game's ONLY selling points:

1. World and character design
2. BGM

Those who are looking for an "RO-like game" in terms of core gameplay
helpfulPercent: don't bother with Tree of Savior. You will be sorely disappointed."

reviewText:
Where to start NOT to buy / play the game..? The game is said to be the 'spiritual successor' of Ragnarok online, but it's not. Though I haven't played Ragnarok a lot, the 2 games differ a lot (too much to be honest), so don't be fooled by that silly 'spiritual successor' crap...

I bought this game during early access and even then the game was loaded with goldsellers - yes this pest really buys into early access games to get a market. Sadly though, the developer (and publisher) is not doing much to battle the goldsellers and you can't even report them from chat (all you can do is block them). That being said, there is said to be a tool available that can recognize, report and block this pest for you. And while it's a helpfull tool, this kind of tools SHOULD NOT be able to be used with an online game, because if this can be used, cheaters can also use hacking tools easily as well!

Then the gameplay... Where to start... If you want to 'kill 10 rats' over and over again, then this game is for you. As a MMO (which is hyped to death!) it's not bringing anything new. It's the same old over and over again and a huge grind for levels to hit cap.
And talking about grind... Changing jobs is yet an other grind. Yes, you can easily select what new job you want, but to get it done be prepared to do numerous 'kill 10 rats' quests before you're even able to talk to that one NPC that can help you progress to your next job.

It's not all too bad though... Graphics are isometric and a very appealing anime style, sound on the other hand feels pretty much out of place for this game and story telling is pretty decent (and corny, but what to expect when almost every tale has been told already :p).

In general I can say it's 'yet an other MMORPG' to fill the ranks. Nothing real special here for my taste and certainly not living up the hype (yes I did read into the game before buying that early access).

reviewText:
I like this game because it reminds me of RO. Decent graphics and game play.

The cons though.. Highly pay to win game and the company will continue to alter the advantage of token to get players to get it.

For players who are not getting the token:
- You level slower
- You get less instance entries (2 per day instead of 3)
- You can only list 1 item in market place, and the item will only appear 2.5 hours after you list it
- You have to farm your guts out to earn silver, so you can use it to upgrade your equipment

reviewText: There is a lot wrong with this game right now, for sure. IMC, the developers, or whoever, need to communicate more openly with the community. The negativity is very strong right now, and for good reason. If you guys don't respond to the community and make it known that you KNOW there are big issues plaguing this game and that you want to fix them, people are just going to keep shouting louder. People desparately want this to be the great game they know that it can be.\n\nAt the core, I know this is a solid game. I was home from work today and was able to play during a low-traffic time, and it was amazing. I was able to connect everytime I tried, the lag was minimal, and I didn't get booted once. This is why there is a such a strong influx of negativity - because people care about the fate of this game. It sounds silly, but it's true! If the game itself didn't have anything to it, it would just quietly die off. For a bit of perspective for those of your just now checking this game out: When it was still in closed beta testing, it had a 9/10 rating. Scrolling through the recommendations was a sea of thumbs up. We're in an early access" period now

reviewText:
Note: This review was pared down slightly due to size limitations.

Tree of Savior can best be described as a mixed bag: before you put your hand in, you better know what you‚Äôre going to get out of it. In this Free to Play MMORPG by IMC Entertainment (Granado Espada, ex Ragnarok Online developers) you start by picking one of four classes and by the end of it you‚Äôre one of eighty. Designed to be a hardcore game, Tree of Savior takes ideas from eastern and western games in its genre and blends them with varying degrees of success. Seeing all the beautiful landscapes and legends based on Lithuanian mythology might take hundreds of hours, but it feels like the game was designed so only the most dedicated players will see even half of it.

Which is a shame, because there‚Äôs no denying that Tree of Savior is a beautiful looking game. By using a mix of 2D and 3D the game treads that line between old and new and occasionally looks like a massive vanillaware game. The area design has been fairly unique from my time with it and I‚Äôve been impressed more than a couple of times just from how it looks. Some of the monsters and items start to repeat as early as 30 levels in though which is a bit of a drag, but I figure they had to cut back a bit since there is enough content for over 200 levels of gameplay.

That‚Äôs right, 200! I don‚Äôt have a number for the amount of different maps total, but I‚Äôve probably seen more than 40 already and I am over level 100. You do see a lot of the standard areas, like a peaceful looking field or a dungeon filled with monsters, but they change it up enough so it doesn‚Äôt get boring to look at. The max level is 280, but the quest content supposedly runs out at about 230, leaving 50 levels of straight grinding to do. That‚Äôs a tall order for anyone, let alone a regular player who just wants to unwind for a few hours during the weekend.

Regular gameplay is fairly simple - designed with a keyboard in mind (but you can use keyboard and mouse or a controller as well), all of your movements are controlled by the arrow keys and spells on the keyboard rows, but you can have more if you like. It plays like an action game where you can dodge attacks and dash and jump, just with spells instead of combos. Dodging can be kind of iffy occasionally, as hitboxes or lag make it tough to jump over ground attacks. Most classes are very skill-heavy but the given layouts are pretty comfortable. Unfortunately the only way to rebind keys right now is by editing a file, which just feels like an obvious oversight.

In fact, I‚Äôd go so far as to say that this game requires a lot of research to get the full enjoyment from it. There is no stat reset and skill resets are only purchased with real money. On top of that there are seven ranks for each class and each one has at least two different and new choices in it, so there are hundreds of build combinations per class, with no way to reset or change your mind when you‚Äôve decided, so you better make it count. It‚Äôs very easy to make a choice you might regret later, which feels very old-school but also a little frustrating for some. I have been in dungeons where players will tell others that they should be reading this big document talking about the nuances to the combat; a lot of things just aren‚Äôt intuitive.

A lot of these minor details have been fixed by the awesome community of the game. There are addons that people have made through LUA scripting and other means that were made to patch holes currently in the game. Gibbed made an addon that shows all the sidequests that you can take, and even displays them on the map so you don‚Äôt have to talk to every single NPC or check every corner of every map for quests. Right now most of these addons are unofficial and haven‚Äôt been approved by designers, but they mentioned that addons are fine as long as they‚Äôre not exploiting the game or giving some players unfair advantages.

Up until now the messaging between players and developers has been pretty good. They listened to the community when they weren‚Äôt happy with the price of their early access server, and they are working to fix the ongoing bot problem that has already cropped up. Even though it‚Äôs a Korean developed game they are surprisingly talkative and have community representatives that are active on their forums. I think the real problem is that some of the issues the game has are going to take a lot more work to fix.

Although beautiful, Tree of Savior is a technical nightmare. I have a decent PC (GTX 760 and a 4590 intel processor) and this game runs very awkwardly, the main reason being that the game doesn‚Äôt use your graphics card at all. In an attempt to be playable on every computer imaginable, the programmers also forced the game to run only on a single core. Combined, these two choices make the game run very sluggishly and with lots of inconsistent frame drops and overall shaky performance. If there are many players nearby the game slows to a crawl. If a lot of enemies take damage at once you might see single digit frames per second. These aren‚Äôt uncommon occurrences either; even with multiple channels per area, you can usually find many crowded areas with players fighting large groups of monsters at once, which looks cool until it tanks the game‚Äôs performance like nothing I‚Äôve ever seen. The good thing is that if you have a PC that can run the game at the bare minimum you‚Äôll probably have the same experience as someone with a great computer, providing an even playing field for all - for better or worse.

Something about the creature AI just doesn‚Äôt feel quite right either. If I attack five monsters at once, occasionally one will just run away which is either a cute feature or an annoyance depending on how you see it. Most enemies are very slow to respond to attacks too, sometimes taking three or four seconds to react to you hitting them which feels very wrong considering how active this game otherwise feels.

Speaking of, spells in this game also feel a little inconsistent. Either a product of lag or poor netcode, spells will sometimes fail to cast even though I charged them up fully. Some spells that don‚Äôt have cast times can be interrupted mid-attack and can be put on cooldown without actually going off while others will be cast regardless, even if I get knocked down. Another annoying thing is enemies clumped together but at different heights can avoid being hurt altogether because of the way the 3D works. This is good and bad as it also allows you to avoid being hit by standing above someone, but it makes playing on hills or slopes fairly frustrating. All these are fairly common occurrences and it makes the game feel sort of incomplete on a technical level.

There‚Äôs a shocking lack of consistency in this game that really makes it feel rushed. I wish they had spent another 6 months fixing the performance and some of the other flaws I mentioned, because it appears a bit unstable. It‚Äôs a shame, because there is so much unique about it but I can‚Äôt look past the technical problems. This game feels like the result of a Korean designer‚Äôs attempt at making a game with a bit of a western feel, similar to what Dark Souls did. Between the layers of complexity and poor performance I fear it that may turn people away once they get frustrated with some of the games‚Äô intricacies, which is a shame because it‚Äôs got a lot of cute details that make it fun and feel full of life. I would recommend trying out the game at least because it‚Äôs free, but know going into it that you‚Äôve got a long road ahead and might have to deal with some issues along the way.

reviewText: Tree of Savior is a great F2P MMO and is my favorite Korean MMO to date.  It's got all that mob grinding we love in a Korean MMO, a fun, great looking art style, plus plenty of quests that you can get lost in for hours. Oh and quick FYI, the music in this game is pretty fantastic.\n\nIt's got some americanized" ideas implemented
recommended: that you earn throughout questing that give you boosts of exp throughout your whole leveling process
hoursPlayed: if you choose to do the quests along side your grinding.  Some of you hardcore grinders might like to grind mobs all the way to the top and this is possible with plenty of places to grind. I like to pickup quests and complete all the zones as I grind my way through because of the Collections and Adventure Journal features that earn you small perks along the way
voteText: if that's your thing. Side note... another thing I love is that the Collections are shared amongst all your characters server wide. So you are always working towards completing them no matter what character you are playing on.  The current max level in English version (aka iTOS) is 280.\n\nThere are currently 4 base classes being Archer
helpfulPercent: Cleric
votesHelpful: Swordsman
votesTotal: and Wizard. From there you can build many different types of characters with around 80 total classes that have their own skills and abilities.  At the time of this writing
votesFunny: each character consists of 7 total ranks and at each rank you choose one of these many classes to add more abilities to your build as you progress. You will want to do a bit of planning on your build before you start getting too far into the game because once you pick a class you are unable to reverse that decision. There are Skill reset(class ability points) and Stat reset (STR
commentsCount: CON
column16: INT
column17: SPR
column18: DEX) potions in the game but they are not available unless you use the microtransaction cash shop or received a Founder's pack before the official release. Also
column19: they only reset your points allocated. Once again
column20: you can NOT reset your classes once chosen. So research a bit and choose wisely! There are some great tools on Fan Base sites that can help guide you in the right directions. Whether you want to see what the current top cookie cutter builds are or make up your own awesome and unique build
column21: its all possible.\n\nThe cash shop in Tree of Savior uses a currency called TP.  TP will get you things like Tokens
column22: EXP Boost Tomes
column24: warp scrolls to get you back to town
column25: etc. Along with cosmetic vanity type items like hairstyles and clothing for your character.\n\nA fun note
column26: in TOS they require the use of an item "Megaphone" to be able to use the /yell chat channel. Megaphones are ONLY accessable on the cash shop for TP.  This seemed weird to me at first but its actually a decent idea to help reduce the gold selling spam bots and lets you decide if that /yell you want to spam is worth the 1TP. The megaphones are 1 TP which means you can easily buy 5 a day when you need to burn your free TP that you earn slowly overtime. Free TP maxes out at 5 and then stops earning so you need to spend it to reset it.  Personally Ive been using TP from my Founder packs and then the  free 5TP to buy a EXP tome per day. It allows me to purchase a Tome for 4 TP instead of the full price of 9 TP. It's not bad for 1HR of 30% xp boost.\n\nYou CAN NOT trade in game currency between players
column27: that includes your own characters. Each of your characters has their own silver.  Though you still see people spamming for trades using other items as currency like Talt (an ore earned from loot boxes on world bosses and dungeons). Talt venders for 5k to venders so its a stable 5k silver coin.\n\nTokens are Tree of Savior's version of that usual F2P "Premium Status". reviewText:
Brutally Charming.
Let's tackle some of the issues players have been having with the game, And some of the misleading reviews, and then let's go on to discuss briefly the actual state of the game as a whole.

Microtransactions
People seem to be very upset with the microtransaction system in place, limiting the features of the game.  This is misleading.  The tokens that give your account premium for 30 days are purchasable through the Auction House in game and are extremely affordable currently.

The Current Cost of a monthly premium token on the Auction House : 500k

The problem arises in that there are still restrictions even with the monthly token.
Are they annoying, yes.  Will it cost you money to unlock premium?  Not at all.

Server Maintenance/Lag Issues
I've been playing MMO's long enough to know that stepping into the grind day one is not the wisest decision.  Every night I receive several rewards in game, and problems get fixed.  It happens.  Personally the biggest problems that friends and myself have encountered so far have already been fixed, but there are some issues that absolutely need to be fixed in the near future, and that I have no doubt will be.  Nothing I would consider game breaking.

Side Note : they have also added two new brand new servers for different world locations since release.  Work is getting done.

Disappointing?  Yes.
Overall?  Expected.

A Warning to New Players
Do not start in Orsha.  No matter what.

I'll be blatently clear about this, This area is unfinished, unpolished, and requires a steadily more intense amount of grind, even including an area from 40-60 where there just simply seems to be zero quests, and nothing to help push you through.  Start in Klaipeda.  The storyline is well polished, satisfying, has many more rewards than the Orsha side, and doesn't brick wall you on your quest to level 300 nearly as often.  Do not confuse this with the server also named Orsha,  I am strictly speaking of the starting city options during character select.

Performance
1. The client needs to be restarted entirely every few hours, I would say 4 is a nice round number to be safe.  Load times can significantly increase as memory does ableit slowly.

2. The game crashes sometimes.  Thankfully it takes a whopping 4 seconds to boot to menu.

3. I get consistantly excellent frames 30-80 during game, and unlike most modern games, your frames do not directly impact the visual appeal or performance of this game in any fundamental way.  It is however extremely noticeable in cities where population can be absurdly high at times.

4.  No matter how hard my internet chokes, burps, deflates, or otherwise acts up, I stay connected to the game and can resume my gameplay without being punished for it. (This may mean a lot to some of you, I thought you should know.)

Current State of the Game/My personal Review
This game is a diamond in the rough.  It's a beautiful, and sometimes brutally charming isometric styled grind em up that wants to be played.  The controller support is excellent, my couch can attest to that, And I don't have to think too much about what I'm doing.  I just like to sit back and explode all the things, and so far I keep getting rewarded for my behaviour and I can appreciate that in a game.  I keep getting these deep Diablo feels, and the game keeps reminding me of its FFT/RO inspirations.

The game is unfinished, put simply.  But I don't seem to mind.  I've been disappointed, engaged, surprised, I've muted the music only to unmute it later, finding that I enjoyed it in the backround.  I've raised a pet by force feeding it silver until it now succesfully headbutts things at the speed of smell.   Ultimately there's a lot I would do to change this game to what I want it to be.  But it's not my game, I'm just here to play it.  And I've been enjoying that so far.

For all my disappointment in it not being the next Tactics Game, It does a lot of things right.  And it keeps it simple, from the gui and large easy to read buttons, to the immediateness of slapping a controller in my palm and booting the game up in just a few seconds.  It's more of a sequal to Maple Story, minus the socialite nonsense.  You just get to look cool, be what you want to be, and kill thousands of monsters.  And that's just what I signed up for.

reviewText:
I would just like to point out that many of the launch problems that are currently being pointed out in the reviews are general launch window problems for most, if not all hyped MMO launches of all kinds.  Free to Play, Pay to Play, Subscription.  After all, would you spend cash for top of the line server gear if the servers are only going to be under this amount of stress for a Month or two, when the expected lifespan of any MMO is several YEARS?

Aside from a CLEARLY fumbled Founder Launch Period, the main complaint of Pay 2 Win sadly something everyone will make because Dota 2 and TF2 offers so much for free already, because Valve can risk losing a boat load of cash.  Something that reletivily indy crew of IMC just dosn't have, so they need to have some more conventional options in the cash shop that Valve can offer for free.

Best I can say is give Tree of Savior some time after the offical Launch and then jump in.  By then, the majiority of complaints currently being seen will be solved, the servers should be stable, and HOPEFULY something has been done about the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•EN GOLD SELLERS SPAMMING SHOUT CHAT!

reviewText:
[This review is from the first 3 hours of the game at level 20 and will more than likely be updated as I get further into the game]

I have went into this one with very few expectations. Not really knowing much about the game, seeing the negative reviews and seeing as the publishers completely screw the pre-order business model up, my hopes for the game were not all that high. Luckily, so far I am yet to run into a blatant intrusion into my gameplay sourced from the cash shop in the game.

[STORY]
I will be honest, while I tried following the story at the start, I rapidly ended up going back to just skipping over NPC text. As far as I can tell, the basic premise if that godesses that were once responding to the prayers of man kind went silent and distasters began to strike the world. While the premise of potentially interesting, I found that the presentation of the story wasn't the most engaging, but that could be just me.

[COMBAT]
Moving onto what is probably the most important aspect of the game, the combat is not the best. Controlls involve moving around with arrow keys/mouse/controller and using a key to do a basic attack, pressing another key to jump. Additionally, each class gets skills to use in combat that can be used from the action bar. Early on, the combat feels really repetitive and perhaps not as engaging as it should be. I can imagine that gaining more skills as you progress would probably alleviate this issue somewhat, however I am not 100% sure on how much more interesting this combat system could get.

[QUESTING]
Questing in the game so far was simple, talk to this NPC, go to this location, do this thing the NPC asked you to do. One aspect I did enjoy about questing however was the fact that most quests are hidden encouraging exploration and engaging with NPCs to find side quests.

[PROGRESSION]
This is by far my favourite bit of the game, the character progression is quite nicely done. At the start, you choose one of 4 classes, then when you are actually in the game, your progression is separated into two halves. Firstly, there is your chaarcter level which detemines your basic stats such as strenght or constitution. Then you have your Class progression which is how you advance your class and learn more skills. Every 15 class levels, you get the ability to advance your character by either developing your last chosen class, or choosing one of the two additional classes you get every 15 levels. This creates some really incredible customisation options and it's probably one of my favourite progression systems for a game of this type.

[GRAPHICS]
This is an interesting one as this game provides a very quite unique artsyle with a very charming asthetic. The game has a very old feel to it, however it looks as a fairly recent game. The stylistic choice to provide simpler animations, less complex feeling world while including a lot of detail into the design creates a very memorable feel to the game.

[AUDIO]
Similarily to the graphics, the audio used in this game is fairly unique. The tracks used for the game have a somewhat classical vibe to them, however they are much more lively, sounding like something that would play at a disco, mixed with something that would be played during an epic, fantastical adventure.

In conclussion, I think this game is definitly worth a go, in the end, its free and in many aspects, quite well done.

reviewText:
First the game has lots of bots and gold sellers.
So the economy is broken some itens cost millions when you barely make 1 million playing all day at end game level.
At the lower level where you could use soem good itens you cant buy them because they are over priced due the gold sellers and bots.

I have 180 hours, barely managed to get my first character to level 160, the game is fun has some potential on the way you can mix character classes, but the way the class tree's work you are bound to see lots of the same builds.
Yeah the game has lots of classes, but you can start on 4 path's:
Wizzard, Cleric, Archer and Swordsman.
Those have their own class tree and you cant mix classes between those different path's.
But you can mix the classes on one of those path's, that can be fun, but for pvp or if you want a character that have sinergy and deal good damage you will be tied to some classes and will not be able to custumize much your character.

The status growth is a joke, for wizzards not only the support classes but the damage dealers to, it's better to upgrade much more your constitution than your int, because the int only upgrade your damage be 1 and after 10 or 20 points it gives you a bonus that barely changes anything.
So a perfect wizzard class for pvp will have 200+ con and barely past 30 int.

So that make this game a little joke for some classes, they relly on flat damage from skill's than damage from status upgrade.

There's some other problems if you want to not be a premium, since you will have some limitations to Auction House and to trade's and some other small things.
But you can be a premium with game currency that you get from killing monsters and the cost is affordable.

The game is fun and all but i cant recommend it the way it's right now, there's some problems with the server where you get disconnected a lot from time to time, and weekends we get rubberband effect a lot, you cant a spell the character move like the spell was done but nothing happens except the monsters dont get the lag and them hit you.

TLDR:
Game need's better staff, hardware, and a revamp on the way status influence the damage.

reviewText:
This is a highly popular anticipated MMO so most reviews are very critical due to glossy expectations and lack of proper research.

At face value, this game has nice visuals/graphics with a very unique class system. There are multiple ways to build your characters and lots of exploration. While the story quests do seem linear, there are plenty of other things to do in the game and additional content is still under development. Definitely very enjoyable with friends but you can play it solo just fine as well.

Some things could be done better. The restrictions on trade have made the market virtually unusable. There are so many RMT spam in chat, lag, and other general issues that all MMO‚Äôs faces. There should be more channels in the higher level maps as the initial group is now pushing through. Some quests don‚Äôt work, but I suspect it‚Äôs the lag which should lighten up in a few weeks.

Word of advice, this game is a VERY EXTENSIVE and you need to do some research before jumping in. It‚Äôs not something you pick up and go. Find some guides, figure out the class system/builds, look into the token system, read the developers announcements, etc.  Buy the early access packages only if you‚Äôre willing to support the developers because face it, you will be dealing with queues/lag/errors until IMC make proper adjustments before it‚Äôs finally release to the public.

A select few are still going to cry over everything. IMC has been VERY accommodating to the community with all the complaints and whiners. They do listen to the community and make appropriate changes. Please don‚Äôt take it for granted. Give them time to sort out any issues and figure out a solution that satisfies the majority.

Overall, it‚Äôs a fun game with common MMO issues. Once IMC fixes it and find the middle ground with the community, people can finally settle down and just ENJOY the game already. Jeez.

reviewText:
Honestly, I haven't played the game very much but the hours I managed to squeeze in were decent.

I enjoyed the new mechanics introduced in Tree of Savior. I was relatively excited about Tree of Savior's release and settled on the idea of purchasing early access. Initially I figured the server might not be as stable because I opted to play earlier. It was to be expected that there would be lag or the occasional glitched quest. I believe Tree of Savior is a brilliant idea and overall a good game.

I enjoyed the soundtrack and the new controls were an interesting twist from what I was accustomed to when I played RO. Of course, there are some changes I felt were odd, but nonetheless I thought the changes from RO to ToS were innovative. Also, I understand that despite who was behind the development of ToS that I would not be able to duplicate the same feelings I had when I played RO with friends; it is a different experience, but that is not necessarily a bad thing. I enjoyed learning a bit of the lore of the game, soundtrack, and the variety of builds.

reviewText:
Like most, I'd be too busy merrily playing the game to write a positive review if I didn't feel hatred for unfair criticism.

This game is actually really, really good: it's the defacto Ragnarok 2. From the same director as Ragnarok (2002), it has the same soul, but is modern. Relationship is very much like between Half Life and Half Life 2, in that the new game doesn't fail to preserve what made the first one so good while impressing you with what you didn't know it could be.

Basically, I'll bet my nuts you'll love this if you loved Ragnarok, or even if you like kawaii ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• in general.

What bothers me is, a lot of people who downvote this game actually love it, but very selfishly (else they wouldn't care to write an angry essay for their $10 spent (or would they?)). Generally, they are missing one of two points:

Maintaining an MMO is expensive; it needs to be paid for one way or the other. If you can't afford $50 on a game that you love, then you should probably be making money instead (if you're too young to, then I'm genuinely sorry for you).

MMOs are pretty much always overwhelmed on their first weeks of service with load issues and bugs. For those who don't realize how stressful it is to fix piles of bugs in a production environment: it's like fixing a car that's currently running at 60mph and you're sitting on top of. It gets much harder to work if you can't maintain peace of mind because crowds are yelling ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• NO WORK" and you're pressed for time as if you're defusing a gas bomb that has already exploded and is currently killing people with gas leaking all over. Have some compassion and be patient

reviewText:
Made by the Devs of RO, TOS is the true 'spiritual successor' of RO; you will enjoy the game more or less depending on how many of the following points you agree with below:

1. You loved RO's 2D sprite/3D world art and general art style
2. Enjoy top-down camera view action RPGs (D3)
3. Love deep customization for RPG classes and/or love deep class and subclassing trees
4. Are ok with the typical grind associated to most Korean MMORPGs and typical slew of fetch quests
5. Like anime
6. Hated RO2
7. Are looking for an MMO with interesting and unique game mechanics in the rpg classes (most of the cool ideas are in the deeper, advanced classes obtained later in the game)

Impressions from CBT:

Overview:
This rpg is like Ragnarok Online, 2D sprites with a 3D world; camera is top-down angled view centered on your character similar to other action RPGs (Diablo 2/3, Dragon Age).

Combat:
Tab targeting system for PvP/PvE with a few aoe/ground-targeting abilities. Bonus % modifiers to exp when partying; Party up to 5. Loot options available while in party. Death penalty is item durability loss for both weapons and armor. (eventually up to zero durability (items cannot break imo)). Durability can be repaired via NPC or other players with the right economy class skills. Quests can be shared/completed with party. Raids/Dungeons exist.

Social:
Typical social features including emotes, chat, party creation, whispering, announcements via megaphone item to scrolling marqee at the top of the UI.

World:
Not seamless world; hybrid combination of party-instanced areas and server-instanced areas connected by portals. Upon entering a portal, there the next area will load with a splash screen during loading. There are dynamically instanced channels depending on server capacity and population per each instanced area in the RPG world.

Classes and Persistent States:
All classes have an associated skill tree and branch from 4 base classes: Swordsman, Cleric, Mage, Archer. Leveling gives you stat points and skill points. Upon reaching key milestone levels, you have the option to either:

1. Unlock new skill trees/subclasses related to the initial base class you chose to be.
2. Choose to 'upgrade' a skill tree you have previously unlocked, in order to put more skill points into existing skills; thus making those skills stronger/more potent.

In short; having chosen a base class, you can either become a jack of all trades/swiss army knife, or a master in a particular specialization. 6 primary stats govern several other derived stats; not too simple nor complex and more info can be found on their wiki.

Pets/Mounts:
There are a few classes that can mount; 3? Pets (as of CBT) can be used to assist you in your adventures. Pets gain levels and need to be maintained (fed, taken care of) and have a relationship rating per created character.

Account:
Multiple characters are allowed per account. Pets are shared at the account level between characters. To my knowledge, accounts are tied to the server in which they are created on, unless some real currency server transfer option is released.

Economy:
Microtransactions for avatar looks and customization; Global market exists for posting items for selling/buying. One on one trading is allowed.

reviewText:
This game is amazing. Aside for the small bugs and glitches that occur at every MMO's launch, I've got to say the game is splendid. It has everything you need, multiple controller supports, frequent challanges/boss battles. The map design is incredible, living, and so much fun to explore everything.

Since the game release 2 weeks ago I've played 88 hours, and I'm still realatively low leveled as there is just so much things to do, gather, work towards for. Not to mention the card system/card battles, they're really fun as well, even though the winner is decided randomly.

Overall dont give in for the negative reviews, sure there are some things need to be changed, but they will be changed according to devs.

reviewText:
I almost didn't try Tree of Savior due to the massive complaints, but so far I feel they are all unfounded. If you're looking for a game that is like Ragnarok Online, only new and improved, look no further. The art, music, playstyle customization, and general gameplay is amazing.

For those who are looking for more information about the general complaints, I've argued against them below, and will update my review as I continue to play.
___________________
Current Level: 179
---------------------------------
The Debate:

The game is extremely grindy"

Rebuttal:
So far
date: I have only done quests and dungeons
recommended: and have never at any point had to resort to mindlessly killing creatures to level. The quests are moderately innovative. While many quests are simply kill quests
hoursPlayed: others involve things such as disguising yourself as monsters to lure other monsters to their death. Dungeons are similar to other modern MMOs
voteText: in that they are instanced
helpfulPercent: and are queued through a party finder. I would argue that this is far less of a grind than any other Asian MMO.\n\nEDIT: It should be metioned
votesHelpful: that when you start the game you choose to start in one of two cities. If you find yourself out of quests
votesTotal: you simply go to the other city and follow the quest chain there. I have heard however
votesFunny: that a wall appears in the mid-100s where there are insufficient quests and grinding becomes necessary. More on this when I hit it
commentsCount:
if I hit it.

"The storyline is terrible"

Rebuttal:
Although it is in no way unique
column16: the storyline isn't terrible. I've found myself actually reading the text more often than I have in other games. Rather than droning on and on and forcing the story down your throat
column17: ToS delivers the story in short succinct dialogues
column18:
which I find far preferable to having to read about every NPC's life story.

"The gameplay sucks"

Rebuttal:
The class variety of ToS is amazing
column19: and allows you to change your class every 15 class levels. Instead of changing your class you can rank it up
column20: to a maximum of rank 3. You retain your class skills every time you change classes
column21: and thus your character becomes a specific blend of what classes you choose to fit your play style. This allows for an immense amount of customization: from your chosen classes
column22: to which skills you decide to invest in within these classes. The gameplay is fluid and engaging
column23:
and lets the player create interesting combinations that other people may not have come up with.


"Everything is locked behind a pay wall"

Rebuttal:
Although the game requires the premium token to utilize numerous functions
column24: the premium token is tradable
column25: and can be purchased from the auction house using in game currency. Premium tokens last for 30 days
column26: and are the only necessary purchase to unlock all of the features of the game. In a way then
column27: this game functions as a subscription game
column28: that can still be played while not subscribed
column29: at the cost of features until a token is purchased using real or in game currency.\n\nEDIT: 4/11 ToS has issued a statement that due to the overwhelming outcry against trade restrictions to non-premium characters
column30:
they are actively working to create a system that will allow for trade for non-premium members. They also are working on a bot/gold-farmer report option to help circumvent current issues.

"The game is full of bugs and lag"

Rebuttal:
I have encountered very few bugs so far
column31: and I honestly wouldn't expect any MMO to be completely bug-free. There are however
column33: and the game seems to devour computer resources in ways it should not. The launch was only a week ago however
column34:
and there is plenty of time for the developers to fix these key issues.


OVERALL: Tree of Savior brings to the table something that feels a lot like Ragnarok Online
column35: only far more refined. The art and music are excellent
column36: and the storyline pulls the player through the game rather than leaving them grinding on the same mobs for hours. The class system allows for an immense level of playstyle customization
column37: and gives each player an individual experience. Although the game virtually demands subscription in the form of premium tokens
column38: paying real money for these becomes less essential in the long run."

reviewText:
Given that I speak from experience ranging from iCBT2 and, as of this time of writing, the early access my views of this game is pretty limited. But here goes:

The game is, despite the staggering amount of people throwing down 10 dollary-doos or more, a work in progress. We got in early to both actually play the game and to see if IMC can handle the numbers we're currently throwing at thim. Needless to say, its been...rocky. CommanderLoadFail and his gang have not been kind to us but given past experiences, what MMO has had a flawless launch? Not too many.

Still with little than less of a month left to go IMC has been dealing with the rampant issue of RMTs, Bots, and possibly the developer's curse of fixing 1 bug and spawning 99 others in its place. As a player I'm generally patient, I don't entirely understand or pretend to know the inner workings of a company when it comes to managing an MMO, so I put my hopes in the team to know what they're doing and not entitle myself to anything. I don't particularly hold this game up to other standards as, again, experience has shown me that I can't expect Game Y to be like Game X, otherwise why not play Game X.

Give this a shot if you have money to spare, if you don't then feel free to wait until Free to Play to give it a dip, Tree of Savior's experience is reminiscent of Ragnarok Online and hitherto vastly different from the MMOs in the current market. Which may in fact be one of the factors that drew so many into this game.

Just keep in mind that it's early access, it basically means an open beta so you're bound to see bugs galore and run into trouble every once in a while.

reviewText:
I don't write reviews often, this probably my second one but I have to, considering how much I enjoy this and plan to throw money at it every so often. I am guessing I am the only person who regrets not getting a better founder's pack?

If you're the type of person who simply likes exploring and collecting achievements, this is something I would highly recommend.

Pros:
-Beatiful Art
-Nostelga Factor
-Easter eggs hidden through the game
-Great Music
-Quests dish out appropriate rewards
-The Grind is incredibly minor compared to other Korean MMOs (More about this below)

Cons:
-Lack of Trading
-Auction House

So aside from the common complaints: bugs, lag, disconnects, gold bots etc, I've rarely ever seen a newly opened MMO not falling victim to these kind of things (there's not a single game I can think of that did have this happen to them at some point). Every single one of them I played had these issues ironed out to an acceptable level. I am looking forward to conditions improving in the future but I bracing myself when the game is open access :P.

I am not sure what IMC games is planning but if they're sticking to their initial claim, they're probably using this founder's pack as a way to gauge and optimize the game for those who are willing to support the game financially. As money oriented as that is, don't forget there's no free lunch, someone has to pay for the maintence and development costs. I'd hate to see this game go under like Ragnarok did: http://adultimum.net/rw/extras.php?section=soappserv

While I don't agree with some of IMC's business decisions, they'll likely change aspects of the game overtime. Honestly their response is pretty much expected; can't really expect a new MMO to over compensate the amount of resources required when their player base is unknown.

I favor grindy games so I am a bit bias but this is nothing compared to old Ragnarok. I got a character to level 70 in about a week or less and at least 20% of my play time is me falling asleep or watching videos on the side while leaving the game on.

The grind can be almost circumvented if you actually take the time to explore the maps and pick-up the hidden quests. Exploring maps and completing quests rewards you with EXP cards which you can beneficial if you plan properly.

Anyone complaining about the grind in this game is either:
+rediculously high leveled (which is expected anyways, so what the heck?)
+tried to get to hit high levels quickly by grinding" and burned out
+simply ignored what the game had to offer"

reviewText:
This is a game about the grind. You must feel the grind, live the grind, love the grind. With a current level cap of 250 which will be increased as time goes on, there is a lot of grinding. If you hate running around in circles and killing things for hours on end, then obviously the game isn't for you.

So what if you do love the grind? Well, Tree of Savior proably still isn't the game for you.

There is a lot to like in this game. The anime artstyle is beautiful, the combat and movement are crisp and fun, and there are some unique classes with cool skills. But to experience those moments, you'll have to fight through a lot of issues. The most obvious issues are bugs that have persisted through the Korean launch and through various open betas, some of which are completely game-breaking (I'm looking at you CommanderLoadFail). If you manage to avoid the bugs, fret not for the server lag will drop your framerate the moment you run into any decently populated map.

Assuming you overlook the more obvious issues, then you will be annoyed by the less-visible issues. Leveled a character over dozens of hours into through several classes only to realize that the abilities or spells have zero synergy with your build? Sorry, start a new character. Want to know exactly how your spells/abilities will scale with stats? Sorry, deal with the vague tooltips and spell/ability descriptions. Excited that there are over 80 classes in the game? Sorry, a lot of those classes just aren't viable due to balancing issues.

Then we have the issues that are downright hilarious. Without a premium 30 day token, players are limited to ONE market slot to sell items, in addition to waiting 48 HOURS to retrieve money from item(s) sold on the market. Since you rely on money to not only upgrade your equipment but also make sure your spells and abilities scale in the game, it really feels like the developers are giving non-premium players a giant middle finger.

Oh, and did I mention that after one of the closed betas the developers took away the ability to buyback items that you may have accidently sold to NPCs? Don't worry though, as the list of items you sold at the bottom of the NPC menus just to taunt you just in case you wanted to be reminded of what bad game design looks like.

Even if you spend the money to skip the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t to have an easier experience, there are still things that can't be fixed by real money, like the class balance issues and the unbearable server-side lag. Given the developer's controversial track record in Korea, and how things still aren't fixed despite being relased early in Korea, it's unlikely there will be fixes that the players have been demanding on any reasonable timeframe.

There is a lot of fun to be had in Tree of Savior, but it is hidden behind a lot of bad game design choices that ultimately sour the gameplay experience. Unless you're just craving something to feed your Ragnorok Online nostalgia or just need a good anime-themed grinder, your time and money probably better spent elsewhere.
voteText: 15 of 29 people (52%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I don't understand why a lot of people have problems with the current game system. I guess the gaming population has become too spoiled that they want to be spoonfed all the time with the features that's only beneficial to them.

ToS is a great game. Unlike what other people say, this is nothing like RO - far from it. ToS has an identity of its own but due to tons of existing MMORPGs, definitely some concepts have been embedded on how the game is played (even the skills have some resemblance to existing games). If there's any flaw I see, it would be their servers but I willing to let that go for now since the game has been officially around for less than a month.

Objectively speaking, its lack of 1:1 trade has become a deal breaker to some players but they must understand that until the management has figured out how to fix stabilize the economy naturally (w/c I'm pretty sure they're working on), we should expect stringent rules. So far, IMC has been proactive so I'm not even worried that they won't deliver. If they don't, it's easy to leave the game -- obviously.

I'm not going to comment a lot on the gameplay, it's refined and the class system is just so versatile. It's grindy but it adds a sense of accomplishment everytime your character reaches a certain milestone.

I'm definitely going to recommend the game to my friends but honestly, I won't encourage them to buy the early access packs since it does not give players any real advantage besides leveling up ahead.

Everything's great except some features which I think are non-factor. Those people who keep on whining should think first on the implications of the existing game system before leaving their judgement which I see is just too focused on the negatives.

I was going to write some more but unfortunately it's game time. See you in-game!

reviewText:
Hello, i played this game, like you can see, a lot. Did CBT and now on OBT.
To be honest this is going to be quick and simple  :
This game = Grinding. Killing mobs but not like a stupid berserker no like a smart tacticians. Not every map is made for grinding, some are and on those maps spawn is quick on others they aren't for a reason.
Second , Grinding, smart grinding. You dont get exp from quest you get card, you are the one to choice WHEN you exp. Are you on a grinding map ? Then no need of those cards. Stay a level or two there.
Also to mention : There are gabs of exp need to level. I guess most of people who aren't use to grind a lot will be block on the second gab zone. Lv 85 to 86 Exp needed = 474,895	. To get from 86 to 87 you only need 20,757. See ? Know when to use cards, know when to grind. SmartGrinding. This sh!t is korean don't forget.
Now that this problem is resolute : LAGS , Yes. Like they said (and this isn't the only time) the last sale day it got really quick. They din't count on that even if they have should. But let them time to cover it up.
About the P2W people are talking about : Dont forget this game is F2P. No money no game. Secondo : In my serv (Orcha) for 500K you can buy a token on market = 1 mounth patrone. Easy. Not easy if you play 2hours/day and if so don't play this game. Next to this the first idea was to avoid bots who is a total faill. If you are a bit infomated about what they do with the community you should know they changed there early access for the community. If community ask at long term i'm sure those things will be no problem. They had to start with something , no ?
About the dungeons : They are caped because you win Talt , Talt is some sh!t you use for guild (i dint have a guild yet so im not sure about what it does) and next to that those are really good grinding zones. Going in a duo (if you can) is a nice place for some easy lvling (exept the lv90 no good exp if i remember good)
Voil√† most of topics i saw god a honest long player view. I LOVE this game i dreamd about a game who would include a class system like this. And i hope people will understant the game launched bearly a week ago and IMC is listening. Give them time !
Cheers.

reviewText:
First the bad:
Netcode is generic and does cause framerate to stop on server lag. Mildly jarring.
Premium service users get more dungeon runs per day, not just more xp. Pretty random. More on the issues with this later.
Can sell 1 item a day, but at least you can sell items at all. (Maybe raise to 5, given premium users can sell 10 now.)
Fee of 30% for selling is also pretty high, but not out of this world, especially since ToS doesn't seem to emphasize crafting like Blade and Soul did (which adequately gave people 10, premium people 20, sells per day. Given how important crafting was there. ToS might be fine with less.). It is quite random that premium users pay less than a third of the fee, though. Leaves a bad taste with me.
Shared storage between characters added as a an afterthought to premium users. Either have it or don't have it, imo.
The neutral:
Like most recent MMOs, there's an emphasis on completing quests to progress, over the classic grind. Can't say that I like this (I prefer the model proposed by games such as Phantasy Star Online or Universe, making people go, as team or alone, through maps, without respawns. Kinda like if the dungeon system was designed to be the main thing people do in the game. Not the bland thing it is right now.), but it could be worse. Just means you will be re-playing the same story over and over and over with new characters. (On that note, please, PLEASE, make cutscenes skipable)
The positive tradeoff is that you can progress pretty fast if you spend your attention on accepting and doing quests. (Outside of dungeons to grind when they come up, because good XP. Here's where I feel giving premium users more runs AND increased XP from killing monsters is just unreasonable.)
The good:
It's a fun game
Fun Gameplay
Enough depth to keep you interested in experimenting with new classes and builds.
Overall, I would recommend this game, because games are about gaming. Not about how much the people in charge have issues with making monetization not a pain. And it could be far worse, so still, give them some credit.

reviewText:
I played this game early access. I don't terribly recommend it, but at the same time, I don't unrecommend it either. I'm basically neutral.

It all comes down to one thing:
I feel this game is toothless.
Perhaps I played a class that just brushed everything aside with just one move and I should've picked a class that actually struggled.
One defining moment happened to me: I entered a level 50 area when I was level 30 and overkilled some enemies with one move. Then I almost died in two hits, but I got to run out, so I was okay by the end of that...
My interest dwindled and was lost and I just stopped playing.


Now, again, I played this game during early access... Maybe they changed somethings that'll make this review pointless. but that's a good thing. There are some good ideas here and perhaps it'll blossom into something that challenges another MMO, like DFO (I guess, since I do play that) to the spotlight.

Good luck!

reviewText:
A quite addictive MMORPG. The linear progression may be it's biggest fault, but it's still a great game to play with friends. Featuring lots of area bosses, hack and slash type of gameplay, and an epic story, it's breathtaking graphics and it's killer soundtrack makes an interesting experience. With over 800 classes combination, easy stats customization, it's easy to get hooked!

Trivial things like percentage of a map viewed completion, number of time a type of enemy got killed are all featured in the ranking system, which makes a great experience for completitionist.

Also, the devs seems to really listen their player base, which is an awesome thing.

reviewText:
Short version: I cautiously recommend Tree of Savior. It's a fun, rewarding gaming experience with some bot/gold spammers issues that are steadily being dealt with. Casual players in particular may enjoy ToS because it's by no means a ‚Äúhard‚Äù game.

Long version

Positives:
1) Fun gameplay
2) Cute (shallow but idgaf)
3) Customizable class system
4) Lag isn't as bad as people say (I'm at a steady 60fps, rarely lag, only had one crazy experience of warping into a completely empty dungeon where my character could fly)
5) Grinding isn't physically/emotionally painful until you hit way higher levels. Casual players can get a sense of satisfaction that encourages them to stick around longer‚Äî (and in turn that's good for the future of the game)

Negatives

1) Community sucks right now. Full of noobs and bots kill stealing in the early dungeons. I've met some super nice people, but overall morons are in the majority.
2) Gold spammers! It's so blatant.
3) BOTS. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• bots being a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• nuisance.

2 and 3 are my main grievances. Spamming/botting is rampant to the point of being intrusive. Ignoring bots is nearly impossible. As soon as I log in my first task is to walk around reporting spammers and botters.

However, response time has improved now that f2p hit. I can only hope the efficiency of the crack down on bots only goes up from here.

(And for my shallow negative: 4) I can't buy male character clothing for my female characters and vice-versa; please let me crossdress my characters! That would make my day.)

reviewText:
If you enjoyed Ragnarok Online and want to play another MMO like it you probably don't need a review. Tree of Savior is very similar, and even improves on a lot of RO's good ideas.

If you never played RO and are curious about ToS, here are the basics: Tree of Savior is a Korean MMO and spiritual successor to the aforementioned Ragnarok Online. It has a anime inspired 2D on 3D artstyle. It looks very good as you can see in the trailer. It is an Action RPG, most closely comparable to something like Diablo. You will either be blowing up large groups of enemies with AoEs, or focusing down one powerful enemy with more strategic single target attacks. They recommend joypad for the best experience, I've just been using keyboard and haven't had any issues.

The game has a very linear quest structure, which makes leveling go by very quickly. The game has a very complex Job system. Every 20-30 levels you will change classes and gain new skills. There are four starting classes, but near infinite possiblities built into each, complemented by the fact that you can build your stats in any way you like as well.

It has all of the modern MMO amenities you would expect: auction house, guilds, instances. I haven't had time to try all of these things, but I did do one instance and it was very pretty fun. The game is packed full of unique features I haven't seen in other MMOs, so if you're someone looking to just try something new you might enjoy Tree of Savior. It's only $10 for early access, and will be free soon.

I must warn you though, the game is a bit of a mess at the moment. Server issues, overpopulation, crashing. Its gotten much better in the past week or so but even if you are starting now expect some issues. I hope they get these problems sorted out before the game goes free to play or it will just get worse. Also be warned that many features are locked to premium members only, which requires real money. Things like trading, selling more than one item on the auction house, and learning multiple skills at the same time. These things are in place to counter Gold sellers, but it is really just punishing the players. I hope they reconsider some of these choices.

Despite these issues the game itself is a ton of fun, highly recommended.

reviewText:
Brought the founder pack and reached level 225 doppelsoelder rank 7 within 3 weeks of gameplay and here are the summary of good/bad experience i encounted thus far;

Awesome artwork
Sick BGM
Lots of Quest to allow you to level you through 1-200 without much monotonous grinding


Could potentially be a great game/complete game but it's pretty much unplayable/not worth playing right now less for the daily dungeon rush; hoping to get something good from lootbox(cubes) which pretty much give junk most of the time.
Game does not reward effort/time spend in game

Tons of classes in the game, however, the viability of these classes are limited because the game is still new and balancing patch has not come in. Most skills of classes do not scale well into higher level.

Mobs/dungeons are not challenging in the sense that they only increase in terms of their Hp/dmg(no mechanics involved, think diablo, what makes it worst is that your skill damage doesn't increase poportionately to their Hp forcing party play at higher level, no room for solo players)
In-game Avatar looks boring - You will probably look the same as many other players
No point grinding end game for loot because mobs don't drop anything
Grinding monster for silver is pointless because of the No. of Botters and rate of inflation
Bots are everywhere(Common in MMO i guess)
Auto-find party are buggy
Afk-er in party during dungeon runs are allowed
Commission in market are 30%, 10% with token(think elite status)
1:1 trade Restriction
takes 48 hours to retrieve money from item you sold on market
Server(Telsiai/Varena) laggy most of the time, 5-30sec delay while interacting with NPC on certain servers
PVP unbalanced to a huge extend
Limited end game maps, can spot a few parties in the same map trying to grind at the same time


TL;DR pretty much unplayable in the current state, but still fun if you are playing with friends on NON-PEAK HOURS and check out guides online before creating a charactor so that you won't risk rolling a unplayable class at the end
